[Robert Penta]: Police, fire, retirement board that needs to be paid.

[Robert Penta]: The deficit as it relates to the retirement fund, $28 million that the city has.

[Robert Penta]: Again, nobody wants to discuss that and how you're going to go forward with that.

[Robert Penta]: And more importantly, a fire and police department.

[Robert Penta]: Does that mean now fire and police are going to be separated?

[Robert Penta]: Or is it not going to be separated?

[Robert Penta]: You haven't even gotten a final answer as it relates to the police department going forward.

[Robert Penta]: If they take down the station over there for the training tower for the fire department, and you're going to go to a regional location, that's going to put the fire department at issue for backup, because they're going to have to send their truck and their men to that regional location.

[Robert Penta]: A public safety issue.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, the Medford Public Schools

[Robert Penta]: as in the commentary from the superintendent, would like to meet with state and local governments as it relates to current code, including fire doors, fire alarms, sprinkler systems, and safety conditions.

[Robert Penta]: All things that right now are in potential violation are, if not in violation, as we presently speak.

[Robert Penta]: After the new, I believe we all can remember, after the new science labs were built, there was a major problem for almost a year where a fire person had to be up at the high school because the fire system, the fire alarm system didn't work as it related to something happened, whether through the electrical department or what have you.

[Robert Penta]: Then, if I understand this correctly, in Mr. Belson's commentary,

[Robert Penta]: And I agree with you 100%.

[Robert Penta]: You said any decision regarding the specific projects and the financial commitments would be developed over time and after multiple meetings within city government and at the state level.

[Robert Penta]: Well, at least he's got the ability to understand and recognize that city government officials need to sit down and discuss it, much more than the person who calls herself the mayor of this community.

[Robert Penta]: This is a big issue, whether you want to realize it or not.

[Robert Penta]: The building is 50 years old.

[Robert Penta]: You're talking about the same fire and police station that's down there right now.

[Robert Penta]: Maintenance didn't take place in the building.

[Robert Penta]: Now, a lot of these things are maintenance driven, whether they be fire, whether they be the windows, whether they be the boiler or what have you, the asbestos.

[Robert Penta]: It's a big building.

[Robert Penta]: I think it's four and a half miles long, Mr. Superintendent.

[Robert Penta]: 550,000 square feet, whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: It was built at a time to be a college campus type of a school.

[Robert Penta]: But that's not the point.

[Robert Penta]: You're getting a lot of this all at once.

[Robert Penta]: Maybe, to some degree, maybe, whether it's the cafeteria or whatever the auditorium is that they... Maybe if you just stuck to the real desperate needs that the building has on a slow annual basis, you can look at these other things and put them into the budget.

[Robert Penta]: Let me just remind you, and I'll just leave you with this last thought.

[Robert Penta]: Just look at the city of Somerville.

[Robert Penta]: Look at all the development that's taken place over there.

[Robert Penta]: All the development.

[Robert Penta]: Okay?

[Robert Penta]: Many, many more jobs, and their taxes keep on going up.

[Robert Penta]: You don't have that opportunity here in the city of Medford, because if we're going to follow the mainstream of Somerville and taxing the citizens of this community to pay for bond indebtedness that you can't afford, and as Council Marks and others have alluded to, you're going to get yourself into a Proposition 2.5 override, it'll lose.

[Robert Penta]: Everyone behind this council, I guarantee you, will lose if you'll be supportive of that, if you're serving at that point in time.

[Robert Penta]: You need to plan ahead.

[Robert Penta]: And when you plan ahead, you'll be able to address these issues.

[Robert Penta]: These have been long overdue.

[Robert Penta]: This is a shame.

[Robert Penta]: Prior school committees ought to hang their head in embarrassment for allowing this to go this long.

[Robert Penta]: And so should the city of Medford, because that's been their downfall, letting their buildings run into a demise situation year in and year out.

[Robert Penta]: And now you're going to pay the price for it.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Name and address of the record, please.

[Robert Penta]: Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., former member of this board.

[Robert Penta]: I understand the resolution is adopted, but the question I would have is that why would you want to charge somebody

[Robert Penta]: a connection fee, because right now you pay from your house to the middle of the street.

[Robert Penta]: So now you're saying that you connect to the city's lines for water and sewer, for which the city charges you for inflow and outflow of the water going through.

[Robert Penta]: We have over $8.5 million in a surplus account that they can't figure out how and where it should be spent as it relates to infrastructure and water-sewer lines.

[Robert Penta]: Now, if you want to talk about doing that for a commercial piece of property, that's one thing, because they're digging up the street, and there's a linkage fee that's attached to it as it relates to it.

[Robert Penta]: But on single-family homes, two-family homes, or whatever it might be, you're already charging the homeowners, already paying for that hookup from the middle of the street to the house.

[Robert Penta]: So I think what you need is probably a further clarification.

[Robert Penta]: as it relates to where it's going on that.

[Robert Penta]: And I think this begs the question, where are you going with your $8.5 million in the surplus account?

[Robert Penta]: Where's the infrastructure?

[Robert Penta]: Where's the LNI that's taking place in the city?

[Robert Penta]: Where are the projects that have been sitting there that need to be addressed?

[Robert Penta]: that the state isn't even going to give you a dime back, because they have no money to give it back to you.

[Robert Penta]: So you're technically putting another tax on the Medford resident taxpayer in this community, and they're getting nothing back for it.

[Robert Penta]: You've got almost $8.5 million in water and sewer.

[Robert Penta]: You've got close to $9 million in your free cash account.

[Robert Penta]: going into 2023 to free up the bonds.

[Robert Penta]: So now you're saying that you connect

[Robert Penta]: to the city's lines for water and sewer, for which the city charges you for inflow and outflow of the water going through.

[Robert Penta]: But on single-family homes,

[Robert Penta]: two family homes or whatever it might be, you're already charging the homeowners, already paying for that hookup from the middle of the street to the house.

[Robert Penta]: So I think what you need is probably a further clarification as it relates to where it's going on that.

[Robert Penta]: And I think this begs the question, where are you going with your $8.5 million in the surplus account?

[Robert Penta]: Where's the infrastructure?

[Robert Penta]: Where's the LNI that's taking place in the city?

[Robert Penta]: Where are the projects that have been sitting there that need to be addressed?

[Robert Penta]: Before you start charging another fee, possibly, to the taxpayer in this community, I mean, you've got a CPA tax that the state isn't even going to give you a dime back, because they have no money to give it back to you.

[Robert Penta]: So you're technically putting another tax on the Medford resident taxpayer in this community, and they're getting nothing back for it.

[Robert Penta]: But you are charging them, and you don't even have a program set aside for what it's going to be used for.

[Robert Penta]: You've got almost $8.5 million in water and sewer.

[Robert Penta]: You've got close to $9 million in your free cash account.

[Robert Penta]: And then they're talking about building all these new buildings that need to be built, that nothing can take place until after 2022, going into 2023 to free up the bonds.

[Robert Penta]: So what are you going to do?

[Robert Penta]: Start taking from your free cash?

[Robert Penta]: Or are you going to do an override of $2.5 for the taxpayers?

[Robert Penta]: Or are you going to start laying off people?

[Robert Penta]: You just spent $14.4 million to build a new Department of Public Works building.

[Robert Penta]: You don't have enough men to do it, to work it on a daily basis.

[Robert Penta]: The problem that I see, and it's just my opinion, that you folks have got no relationship with this mayor.

[Robert Penta]: You absolutely have nothing to do with her on anything in this.

[Robert Penta]: She just uses you for whatever she wants, when she wants.

[Robert Penta]: Listen, if this is going to be cohesive in a working relationship, you people need to put your foot down.

[Robert Penta]: It only takes four of you.

[Robert Penta]: Four of you have enough intestinal fortitude to tell the city administration enough is enough.

[Robert Penta]: Because I'll tell you right now, you folks keep going in this direction, your election this November is going to have a different audience out there and behind this rail.

[Robert Penta]: Because people are fed up with the fact that they're paying for something, they're not getting it, there's no cooperation, there's no fluidness, there's no transparency, and there's no honesty coming out of this building.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Oh, okay.

[Robert Penta]: Name and address of the record, please.

[Robert Penta]: I wouldn't be that rude.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: Good evening.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Pinter.

[Robert Penta]: I live at Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., a former member of the Saugus party.

[Robert Penta]: I have some concerns as it relates to whatever this agreement might be between the city and the fire department.

[Robert Penta]: And the one glaring thing that stands out with me is that the mayor is going to appoint a committee of fire personnel to work as it relates to a new fire station or whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: Why didn't that take place for the police department?

[Robert Penta]: If she's so concerned about the fire department, it's obvious that then she was less concerned about the police department.

[Robert Penta]: And it's quite obvious by this particular writing here.

[Robert Penta]: And it's more obvious because of the fact that no one from rank and file of the police union were part and parcel of where we're going with all of this.

[Robert Penta]: Second thing, as it relates to the location or relocation possibly of a new fire station, the chief is here.

[Robert Penta]: He can answer for himself.

[Robert Penta]: But last night, he indicated that the present location is the best place for the fire

[Robert Penta]: location here in the city of Medford for its headquarters.

[Robert Penta]: So we take that into consideration because the talk seems to be supposedly getting a new fire station at a new location at a later time.

[Robert Penta]: And then we go to point number four where the mayor says she's going to submit a loan order no later than the 2019 fiscal year.

[Robert Penta]: That brings you up to May of June of 2020, no later than that.

[Robert Penta]: But all you're going to be getting

[Robert Penta]: is allegedly a proposal for one, a new station.

[Robert Penta]: And number two, you know, maybe what the cost is going to be.

[Robert Penta]: There's no proviso in here as it's going to relate to how it's going to be paid for, whether it's going to be the Medford taxpayer, because we know right now there's no grants.

[Robert Penta]: She's still looking for grants, as she said last night, she's on the hunt.

[Robert Penta]: And in some places there's no grants to be found.

[Robert Penta]: So you're looking at Mr. And Mrs. Medford taxpayer who seems to be the person that's going to be paying it.

[Robert Penta]: So I think you have some financial concerns that really need to be taken into consideration.

[Robert Penta]: Nothing that's been discussed right now is an obligation of the city.

[Robert Penta]: It's approximate $28 million pension deficit.

[Robert Penta]: You folks haven't mentioned that yet.

[Robert Penta]: And there's no upticking on paying that down at a faster rate because the interest rates keep going higher.

[Robert Penta]: The other night there was a contract, excuse me, there was a meeting as it relates to a multi-million dollar refurbishing of Medford High School.

[Robert Penta]: It's going to cost factor that's going to have to come in.

[Robert Penta]: Most recently, this council voted on, and excitedly, for the Medford Library and a $20 million bond.

[Robert Penta]: And if that comes through, there's a 40% payback on the city side.

[Robert Penta]: These are things that really have to be taken into consideration.

[Robert Penta]: And you, President Caraviello, in your first term, on the second year of your first term, you introduced a document that talked about $1.3 million of necessary repairs on the six new schools.

[Robert Penta]: That's up to almost a million point five right now.

[Robert Penta]: This city has a bad history of taking care of its buildings.

[Robert Penta]: The private administration ignored all these buildings.

[Robert Penta]: This city council is now being faced with altogether, all at once, a whole host of issues.

[Robert Penta]: It's obvious that the priorities have not been set.

[Robert Penta]: But the priorities of this particular mayor, her little baby, being this police department thing, and now with the fire department thrown in, she should be here discussing this and making her plea with you folks.

[Robert Penta]: This is totally unfair.

[Robert Penta]: You folks have never had an opportunity to discuss this issue, never mind the location, never mind the 35,000 square foot building, never mind a three-story building, never mind the fact that if you put a combined operation there, according to Dunn and Sweeney, it won't even fit today's standards.

[Robert Penta]: And if you look at the 600 plus pages of the report, it alludes to the fact that even if you were to build a new police station and leave the fire station alone,

[Robert Penta]: What you're going to have is you're going to have mechanical problems that also will have code problems that will not bone up for the next 20 years.

[Robert Penta]: And that's going to be a cost factor to take into consideration.

[Robert Penta]: If you're talking about a possible 10 to 18 month period or 10 to 12 month period for a designer to come in and an OPM person hired first, everyone keeps forgetting to say that.

[Robert Penta]: The OPM needs to be hired first.

[Robert Penta]: Once you put that together,

[Robert Penta]: Why wait and do an 18-month period?

[Robert Penta]: Why can't you do both at the same time?

[Robert Penta]: And if you do both at the same time, maybe you can work out a process that basically says you can build this station in increments.

[Robert Penta]: as it relates to building a new police station, and then working on the fire station.

[Robert Penta]: Because we all know on the fire station side of the building, the building is probably in better shape and in better condition than the police side.

[Robert Penta]: But who's to say it isn't, because nobody's gone through there, and Councilor Longo hit it right in the head, maybe you should go in there and have any equality.

[Robert Penta]: Maybe that building should be reviewed for its aesthetic qualities, and whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: You know, running around not having any money from the outside, and only dealing with approximately $9 million in your free cash,

[Robert Penta]: That doesn't leave an awful lot, because then we can talk about your almost $8 million that you have in your water and sewer account, for which Mr. and Mrs. Medford taxpayer has been paying for, and a surplus just sits there, and there is no ongoing proposed work.

[Robert Penta]: And you're hitting the taxpayers with that money.

[Robert Penta]: You're also hitting the taxpayer with the CPA, the Community Preservation Act, which in effect is almost $1 million plus you're taking away from the taxpayers, and there is no known program for it.

[Robert Penta]: So how much can you keep going back to Mr. and Mrs. Taxpayer and say to them, we're charging you for this, this is what the cost is going to be, and readily acknowledge by our own treasurer the fact that the matter is there's going to be some deficit mode as you continue to go forward that's going to have to be offset.

[Robert Penta]: Who's going to pay for it?

[Robert Penta]: Do you really want to tell the taxpayer you need a Proposition 2.5 override?

[Robert Penta]: Do you really want to sell that?

[Robert Penta]: And if everything comes before you, Mr. President, before your council,

[Robert Penta]: Okay?

[Robert Penta]: Where's the conversation as it relates to that?

[Robert Penta]: Where's the priority going to be?

[Robert Penta]: Is it going to be the high school?

[Robert Penta]: Is it going to be the library?

[Robert Penta]: Is it going to be the police department?

[Robert Penta]: Is it going to be the fire station?

[Robert Penta]: The fire chief made an excellent point, something I never even thought of, and thank you for bringing it up.

[Robert Penta]: Talking about storage.

[Robert Penta]: If you can't even store what you have on the property that you have right now, where in God's creation are you gonna put that?

[Robert Penta]: He said possibly auctioning it off, two bays you're gonna possibly be losing.

[Robert Penta]: You talked about regionalization the other night.

[Robert Penta]: The mayor readily said that we could possibly go to regionalization.

[Robert Penta]: And I believe we heard the fire department indicate and say to you that if we did go to regionalization and we did take one of our trucks and a group of our guys to go there and to do whatever it might takes place at one of these fire academies, so to speak,

[Robert Penta]: There needs to be a backup here in this city.

[Robert Penta]: And where's the backup to the backup in the city?

[Robert Penta]: God forbid there's a major fire that takes place.

[Robert Penta]: These are things that haven't been discussed.

[Robert Penta]: That's what you folks should be discussing before you rush into this thing and say we want to go forward.

[Robert Penta]: There is nobody, not one person in this room that would be against a fire in a police station.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think there's anybody.

[Robert Penta]: We'd all be crazy if there was one person.

[Robert Penta]: We all recognize the fact that the need is there, but we also recognize the fact that the city has been extremely diligent and not maintaining its buildings.

[Robert Penta]: But there needs to be a priority that's set.

[Robert Penta]: There has to be a goal set here, and there has to be a timeline met.

[Robert Penta]: And if it's 2022 that was stated last night, now it's up to 2024 before you start to be making these paybacks, what's the cost going to be as it relates to the new station?

[Robert Penta]: Mr. McCulloch made an excellent point.

[Robert Penta]: And the point is simply this.

[Robert Penta]: If you have to buy another piece of property for $10 million, is the at-present property worth $10 million?

[Robert Penta]: Are thereabouts?

[Robert Penta]: And if it isn't, but it comes close to it, and between the sale and the taxes that it generates, it offsets the cost of where you might be going.

[Robert Penta]: These are things.

[Robert Penta]: And I thank you folks.

[Robert Penta]: I think it was you, Councilor Lungo-Koehn, who asked to maybe go into executive session to find out who are these other people that the city sat down and spoke with as it relates to possibly moving it around.

[Robert Penta]: You seem to forget one thing as it relates to where the public works department is, because we can't put any equipment in there.

[Robert Penta]: But the new public works building was being discussed.

[Robert Penta]: What was discussed before this council was building something that could be oversized, not only to handle public works, but to handle our other buildings, whether it be our fire trucks, our police cars, and whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: And there was a pushback by the then administration.

[Robert Penta]: Why was there a pushback?

[Robert Penta]: I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: And there was also a thought process that told us we could just wrap the whole thing around public works, fire, and police.

[Robert Penta]: And all you would be doing is asking and moving people that are presently there without taking their property, moving their property, so nobody would lose any space.

[Robert Penta]: As a matter of fact, they'd probably have better space, they'd have front view space, but you'd still have the availability of a fire department that's right there in the middle of the square.

[Robert Penta]: Police department, maybe move back a little bit one way or the other, but they can get around with their cars a lot quicker than a fire truck could.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think you should make a mistake by saying, no, we're not going to vote for this, or yes, we're going to vote for that.

[Robert Penta]: It's the process.

[Robert Penta]: And once again, the process has been broken down.

[Robert Penta]: It's been broken down because there's been no communication, a lack of leadership from the mayor's office with this council.

[Robert Penta]: And all you folks are being required to do is to vote for this thing up and down with absolutely not an ounce of input.

[Robert Penta]: And today is another perfect example of what took place.

[Robert Penta]: If the fire department can meet with the mayor to get this resolution between themselves, then why wasn't the council involved before or after?

[Robert Penta]: And who's to say that this mayor is going to be here in 18 months?

[Robert Penta]: That's the question.

[Robert Penta]: And that's what you need to ask yourself.

[Robert Penta]: So why are you going out on 18 months when in fact, if you're going to be doing this thing for a police department, why don't you do it for a fire department at the same time?

[Robert Penta]: That way they'll have a better understanding and a better acknowledgement to the fact where the fire and police can be housed together like they were in 1962 and like the report said.

[Robert Penta]: That report of multiple pages from Dunham and Sweeney going back to 2013 is probably the best example that you can have to tell you and to show you why

[Robert Penta]: a dual building should work.

[Robert Penta]: But if not, and you decide to go separately in a separate way, that generates and should generate positive discussion.

[Robert Penta]: And one last thing for Mr. Falco, Councilor Falco, when you talked about that training tower, while it seems to be something that, you know, it's going to be there, it might cost $500,000,

[Robert Penta]: But where in the city is it going to be?

[Robert Penta]: And you don't want that to be regionalized.

[Robert Penta]: Because if you want that regionalized, you're taking firefighters out of service, out of our community.

[Robert Penta]: You're taking a truck out of our service, out of our community.

[Robert Penta]: You're putting backup there, and there's nobody there for the backup.

[Robert Penta]: And that's the problem that we're going to have.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, you just don't like me, so that's your problem, Councilor Dello Russo.

[Robert Penta]: The people out there have elected you people.

[Robert Penta]: We're voting on the motion.

[Robert Penta]: On your motion, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: On the motion, but apparently, as Councilor Longo-Kearns alluded to, it is contradictory to the point number C. Councilor Longo-Kearns is a resolution that will go to the mayor's office.

[Robert Penta]: It's the mayor's, it's not the mayor's privilege, it's the council's privilege.

[Robert Penta]: It's your prerogative, not the mayor's.

[Robert Penta]: On the loan order in and of itself.

[Robert Penta]: It's your prerogative, not prerogative, not the mayor's prerogative.

[Robert Penta]: And you've already voted on point number C, which is contradictory to the main motion.

[Robert Penta]: No, we agreed.

[Robert Penta]: But where in the city is it going to be?

[Robert Penta]: And you don't want that to be regionalized.

[Robert Penta]: Because if you want that regionalized, you're taking firefighters out of service, out of our community.

[Robert Penta]: You're taking a truck out of our service, out of our community.

[Robert Penta]: You're putting backup there, and there's nobody there for the backup.

[Robert Penta]: And that's the problem that we're going to have.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: You do not get into the roll call vote.

[Robert Penta]: He can speak as many times as he wants.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, you just don't like me, so that's your problem, Councilor Dello Russo.

[Robert Penta]: The people out there have elected you people.

[Robert Penta]: We're voting on the motion.

[Robert Penta]: On your motion, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: On the motion.

[Robert Penta]: But apparently, as Councilor Longo-Kearns alluded to, it is contradictory to the point number C. Councilor Longo-Kearns, there's a resolution that will go to the mayor's office.

[Robert Penta]: It's not the mayor's privilege.

[Robert Penta]: It's the council's privilege.

[Robert Penta]: It's your prerogative, not the mayor's.

[Robert Penta]: On the loan order in and of itself.

[Robert Penta]: It's your prerogative, not the mayor's prerogative.

[Robert Penta]: And you've already voted on point number C, which is contradictory to the main motion.

[Robert Penta]: We are voting on the loan order, Councilor Penta.

[Robert Penta]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Robert Penta]: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penter, former member of the Zargas Party, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: I'd like to go over some points that were brought up.

[Robert Penta]: Unfortunately, the whole meeting wasn't televised.

[Robert Penta]: But it was probably a misreading on your part, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: It's not a 3,500 square foot building.

[Robert Penta]: It's a 35,000 square foot building.

[Robert Penta]: That's number one.

[Robert Penta]: Number two, in the report, it states it's going to be three stories.

[Robert Penta]: And our good friend, the city solicitor has been quoted by saying that the mayor said she has decided where the building is going to go.

[Robert Penta]: The sad part about this whole commentary is the mayor is proposing an excess of a 22 and a half million.

[Robert Penta]: And we don't even know what the contingencies might be.

[Robert Penta]: proposal here for the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: This present city council, this will be the largest financial bonding that you folks are going to be doing.

[Robert Penta]: And because of that, and because of that, I agree with Councilor Marks, the mayor should be here tonight.

[Robert Penta]: This is her proposal.

[Robert Penta]: Because when she announced when she was campaigning, it would be seven to eight years.

[Robert Penta]: How it got sped up to this point, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: But thankfully because of the police department going out there and having their demonstrations and speaking up

[Robert Penta]: and folks coming forward saying it's about time.

[Robert Penta]: But there are some issues.

[Robert Penta]: Councilor Lungo-Koehn is correct.

[Robert Penta]: You don't have any report in front of you that talks about dates, places, people that you met with, whoever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: And if some of the landowners that were supposed to have met with the city did not want their names mentioned, you could go into an executive session and that would protect it.

[Robert Penta]: At least you would have an idea who they were, where the locations might have been.

[Robert Penta]: There wasn't one police union representative on this committee.

[Robert Penta]: So what does that tell you there?

[Robert Penta]: Where was their involvement on this particular location for whatever it might be?

[Robert Penta]: The other part about it is the city council, you folks had no involvement at all.

[Robert Penta]: You're hearing about it for the first time last week and at 10 o'clock last week, you get a phone call or an email saying there's a press announcement the next day.

[Robert Penta]: That's great for transparency.

[Robert Penta]: This administration was going to be so transparent.

[Robert Penta]: It's about as transparent as this rug on the floor.

[Robert Penta]: More importantly, going forward, the fire chief not being involved, not even being consulted.

[Robert Penta]: I can't answer for the chief of police, because I did speak with him last Tuesday night at the council meeting, and there was going to be an announcement the next day.

[Robert Penta]: Whether he knew what the announcement was or not, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: We didn't get to the finality of it.

[Robert Penta]: But if the fire department, like they are here tonight, have a particular purpose to this thing, then it should be brought into play.

[Robert Penta]: Now let's talk about the bonding.

[Robert Penta]: because if you get into the Dun and Sweeney report, which is dated January of 2013,

[Robert Penta]: as Councilor Marks has alluded to.

[Robert Penta]: There is a funding mechanism here that needs to be addressed.

[Robert Penta]: And the funding mechanism that needs to be addressed is that if you leave that fire department alone, the way it is right now, and just go with a police department, you have a bonding situation for which this city council is going to be paying for whatever the rate's gonna be to bond the police station.

[Robert Penta]: But over the next 20 years in the life of the bond, that Medford Fire Department and its headquarters are not going to be up to code.

[Robert Penta]: mechanically, electrically, and whatever else is needed by the standards as we go further in time.

[Robert Penta]: So to take into consideration the possibility of having a police and a fire department put together, or mixing the two together, how these two buildings can merge themselves together, how you can add or subtract to it, that should be the discussion before you say the final, the police department, that's it.

[Robert Penta]: Isn't it best to sit down and discuss these things?

[Robert Penta]: rather than she made the decision.

[Robert Penta]: Who is she to make the decision with the taxpayer's money and then she puts you guys in a corner and girls in a corner, boxing you in like a rubber stamp.

[Robert Penta]: If you don't vote for it, that means you're against it.

[Robert Penta]: That's not true.

[Robert Penta]: What's true is you should be a part of it.

[Robert Penta]: We're all part of this.

[Robert Penta]: whether we're a taxpaying citizen, an elected official, the mayor, whoever we're being.

[Robert Penta]: But more importantly, you have fire and police out here.

[Robert Penta]: And to some degree, they are divided.

[Robert Penta]: Because you know something?

[Robert Penta]: The fire department is starting to realize things that they need.

[Robert Penta]: Just because there's a $2,500,000 inclusion in the capital improvement program, what does that say?

[Robert Penta]: Where is that going?

[Robert Penta]: How does that affect them on their side of the building?

[Robert Penta]: You just gave over $300,000 a few weeks ago for their turnout gear, but they've only got one set of washing machines.

[Robert Penta]: 6, 3, and 2, if I understand those bond houses, 6, 3, and 2 would like to have washing machines that are very expensive.

[Robert Penta]: Well, why wasn't that brought up as a subject matter?

[Robert Penta]: Is that gonna be something that's gonna be a challenge?

[Robert Penta]: Well, I would hope not.

[Robert Penta]: You pay for one thing, but you don't pay for another.

[Robert Penta]: Another thing is there is absolutely no detailed analysis.

[Robert Penta]: The city treasurer is here.

[Robert Penta]: She has not presented, neither has the mayor presented you a detailed analysis of bonds that are going to be terminating.

[Robert Penta]: And by those bonds terminating, the city can just transfer themselves over to paying the same amount that those bonds were paying that would pay for this project.

[Robert Penta]: I want to see that.

[Robert Penta]: As a taxpayer and as an elected official, you need to see that.

[Robert Penta]: Because is the city saying your taxes won't go up?

[Robert Penta]: Your rates won't go up because of this?

[Robert Penta]: And where is all the grants from the federal government and the state?

[Robert Penta]: The city of Malden got $9 million in grants before they started their project to build an $18 million building.

[Robert Penta]: Where is the one grant from the federal government or the Commonwealth of Massachusetts?

[Robert Penta]: Has anyone received one?

[Robert Penta]: Have you become aware of it?

[Robert Penta]: You don't even know if they've even applied for it.

[Robert Penta]: It would have nice to know that if you had a sense of conversation.

[Robert Penta]: And if you, Mr. President, being the leader of this body, had the mayor invited you in at least at minimum to have a conversation about this, you could at least bring some information back.

[Robert Penta]: But she shut you out too, which is wrong.

[Robert Penta]: You can't do it by yourself, your own way.

[Robert Penta]: You know,

[Robert Penta]: You get elected to do a job.

[Robert Penta]: You talk about being transparent.

[Robert Penta]: You talk about being independent voices.

[Robert Penta]: How can you be an independent voice if you shut out, if you're not part of the situation, you're not part of the process?

[Robert Penta]: You know, we spent $110,000 for a Denham and Sweeney's report in January of 2013 that was presented to the council in 2014.

[Robert Penta]: You had a Committee of the Whole meeting where there were a lot of issues that were brought up.

[Robert Penta]: And I don't think any one fireman or any one police woman or lady, police man or lady, excuse me, or a fire lady and a fireman, I don't think they want to see any division between and amongst themselves, because I certainly don't want it, and I don't think the city needs it.

[Robert Penta]: But this is crunch time right now.

[Robert Penta]: You're talking about a subject matter that's now involving both fire and police.

[Robert Penta]: And unless the city administration says that the fire department is not going to be involved in this, this is just a police issue, a police building issue, and a police department issue, then I think you have a problem, because the problem is now presenting itself before you.

[Robert Penta]: The report talks about a merger of the buildings.

[Robert Penta]: It talks about the irregular space that you have over there.

[Robert Penta]: It also talks about having a minimum of three and a half acres to have a modern, up-to-date fire and police department that can take you into the next generation.

[Robert Penta]: You're only dealing with more than two and a half acres of land.

[Robert Penta]: So your space requirements are already confined.

[Robert Penta]: And to build a three and a half story building, who made that determination?

[Robert Penta]: Where's the parking facility going to go?

[Robert Penta]: And if you're going to have a schematic design?

[Robert Penta]: You talk about something that's going to take place over the next six to eight months.

[Robert Penta]: Six to eight months are going to prove to be what?

[Robert Penta]: You're going to go out there for a design.

[Robert Penta]: But to get to the six to eight months, you guys have to make a decision.

[Robert Penta]: You're going to have to agree and disagree on things.

[Robert Penta]: And you're going to have to move forward.

[Robert Penta]: And you're going to have to have people input, your input.

[Robert Penta]: Taxpayers' input, it's their money.

[Robert Penta]: It's the taxpayers' money.

[Robert Penta]: And I can guarantee that every single police officer and every single fireperson can come up to this podium and say that they need what they need to do their job.

[Robert Penta]: They should not be denied, but they should have the option of knowing that every conceivable option was presented and discussed and voted upon.

[Robert Penta]: It wasn't squirreled into a particular corner, a particular group, on a particular day, and then we'll talk about the next issue on another day.

[Robert Penta]: The stupidest way to waste money is to spend it recklessly.

[Robert Penta]: And right now, I think you would be doing that before you sit down and take into consideration all the needs that are out there.

[Robert Penta]: Why would the capital improvement program have a $2.5 million inclusion for the fire department?

[Robert Penta]: without you folks knowing about it, but you're dealing with a $2 million requirement to go out there and have a schematic design, and then a $20 million to build a building, and how do you know if that building, in effect, is gonna have any effect at all on the fire department, or vice versa?

[Robert Penta]: You don't know.

[Robert Penta]: You know, we live in a great city.

[Robert Penta]: We have a great group of people in here, and we all wanna do the right thing, the best thing for our community.

[Robert Penta]: But we need to be smart, and we need to be inclusive, and we need to be,

[Robert Penta]: understanding that we all can't think the same way.

[Robert Penta]: But if you can't think the same way without having an opportunity to talk about it, you'll never be able to accomplish anything.

[Robert Penta]: Today is Valentine's Day, and I wish you all a happy Valentine's Day.

[Robert Penta]: But with the white Christmas lights outside, I'm a little bit confused, okay?

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Name and address for the record please.

[Robert Penta]: Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Bedford, Mass, former member of this board.

[Robert Penta]: You know, this is the problem that's happening here.

[Robert Penta]: Councilor Knight just hit it right in the head.

[Robert Penta]: You have questions to be asked.

[Robert Penta]: You've waited some 15, 20 years.

[Robert Penta]: The chief says it's been some 20 years looking for a new police station.

[Robert Penta]: It's not gonna happen overnight.

[Robert Penta]: You're gonna have to take six to eight months before you even get the groundwork going.

[Robert Penta]: Let me make an offering here that maybe you folks through the presidency, go to the mayor tomorrow morning, because I saw her walking out of the building tonight.

[Robert Penta]: Apparently she decided not to come to the meeting.

[Robert Penta]: This is her baby.

[Robert Penta]: This is not your baby, it's her baby.

[Robert Penta]: She's the one that made the presentation.

[Robert Penta]: You tell her that you wanna sit down and talk with her,

[Robert Penta]: You have all the questions you wanna ask.

[Robert Penta]: It would be nice, maybe the first time in some, what, 16 months, that you had an opportunity for all of you to sit down, break some bread in our office, and just saying, hey, these are the questions we're going, let's do this all together, and maybe you can come to some sense of resolution.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think a week or two is gonna make any difference right now.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think a first reading is gonna make any difference.

[Robert Penta]: Because the fact of the matter is, you don't have your questions answered.

[Robert Penta]: And until those questions are answered, you're not gonna be able to go anywhere.

[Robert Penta]: You know, Councilor Falco, you had a concern over the tower, okay?

[Robert Penta]: You know, you don't have that answer yet, but we can get into all the minutia of the questions that need to be asked.

[Robert Penta]: So why don't you just reverse it?

[Robert Penta]: Call her up tomorrow morning.

[Robert Penta]: 8.30 when she comes to work, like everybody else at City Hall, 8.30 in the morning, go knocking on her door and just saying, we're having a meeting with you, Madam Mayor and the City Council.

[Robert Penta]: She needs you.

[Robert Penta]: You don't need her.

[Robert Penta]: Remember that.

[Robert Penta]: You're her breadstrings.

[Robert Penta]: You're her lifeline.

[Robert Penta]: And if you don't hold her feet to the fire, she'll just use you each and every time she wants something done for her, to make her look politically good, and to embarrass you folks.

[Robert Penta]: And right now, that's the position you're in, an embarrassing position, but you don't need to be.

[Robert Penta]: Now's the time to turn around, put your big boy suits on, and your shoes, and your girl, and your high heels, and go knock on that door, and say, we're here to do business.

[Robert Penta]: If you wanna do business, we're ready to do it.

[Robert Penta]: If not, we're shutting down.

[Robert Penta]: That's what I would do.

[Robert Penta]: You know, you don't have that answer yet, but we can get into all the minutiae of the questions that need to be asked.

[Robert Penta]: So why don't you just reverse it?

[Robert Penta]: Call her up tomorrow morning.

[Robert Penta]: 8.30 when she comes to work, like everybody else at City Hall, 8.30 in the morning, go knocking on her door and just saying, we're having a meeting with you, Madam Mayor and the City Council.

[Robert Penta]: She needs you.

[Robert Penta]: You don't need her.

[Robert Penta]: Remember that.

[Robert Penta]: You're her breadstrings.

[Robert Penta]: You're her lifeline.

[Robert Penta]: And if you don't hold her feet to the fire, she'll just use you each and every time she wants something done for her, to make her look politically good, and to embarrass you folks.

[Robert Penta]: And right now, that's the position you're in, an embarrassing position.

[Robert Penta]: But you don't need to be.

[Robert Penta]: Now's the time to turn around, put your big boy suits on, and your shoes, and your girl, and your high heels, and go knock on that door and say, we're here to do business.

[Robert Penta]: If you want to do business, we're ready to do it.

[Robert Penta]: If not, we're shutting down.

[Robert Penta]: That's what I would do.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., former member of the Saugus party.

[Robert Penta]: I don't have any problems with the requests that are being made, but my problem is in the process that's being presented here to you this evening.

[Robert Penta]: What seems to be unfamiliar is the fact that this present administration talked about this issue of inclusion and being a part of what's taking place.

[Robert Penta]: You have the police, the forestry, the engineering department, the cemetery, the highway, and the fire department.

[Robert Penta]: Six departments that you folks, during budgetary time, have heard all of these concerns that are being presented here tonight.

[Robert Penta]: And as a matter of fact, it goes back to the times when I served in this body where some of these issues were there.

[Robert Penta]: This money is coming out of free cash.

[Robert Penta]: And because it's coming out of free cash, which was asked for before, you folks were told, or we were told, as well as you folks were told, at some point in time, we can't use it because it might have an effect upon the bond rating here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Now, all of a sudden, it's coming out as a $1,100,000 transfer of money.

[Robert Penta]: And tomorrow night, Madam Mayor is going to be making her presentation for the State of the City's Address.

[Robert Penta]: My concern would be if there are more things that are going to be coming that's going to have a cost impact upon not only free cash or maybe even bonding, I think before this vote takes place, I think it probably should be laid on the table for one week, as Councilor Lungo-Koehn rightly did some weeks ago on the request of the $900,000 to have some transfer of money from the Water and Sewer Account to pay for the remediation of the West Medford parking lot.

[Robert Penta]: Now, you folks have your own rules.

[Robert Penta]: and it's rule number 20, section number four, which states that any finance paper appearing on the council agenda for the first time shall be automatically laid on the table for one week when such action is requested by any councilor.

[Robert Penta]: I would think it would be wise by this city council, I'm not saying for you to not vote for it or vote for it, I think it would be wise to lay it on the table for a week and just see what's going to be presented tomorrow night in the state of the city's address.

[Robert Penta]: You folks, unfortunately, have been kept not in the loop.

[Robert Penta]: Everything that's being presented here has nothing to do with you folks.

[Robert Penta]: You folks have never met with all the department heads to go through their wish lists.

[Robert Penta]: That was something that was discussed during this past election, and it still hasn't taken place.

[Robert Penta]: A magnificence of $1 million here tonight, and the mayor's representative is not here.

[Robert Penta]: That doesn't speak well.

[Robert Penta]: One information council tonight.

[Robert Penta]: I believe the mayor has four representatives here this evening.

[Robert Penta]: The mayor's liaison to the City Council is not here tonight.

[Robert Penta]: Department heads might be here, but they're not the ones that bring the message back.

[Robert Penta]: You know, when you go back and you look at some of these things and you say to yourself, the chief of police just thought through saying six cruises, six new, six regular cars and six cars that are going to be unmarked.

[Robert Penta]: I think this council in the past has asked for each and every year,

[Robert Penta]: Chief, you can correct me, for a minimum of two new cars each and every year in the budget.

[Robert Penta]: This should have been, you folks should have been dealing with this within the past year, if not more.

[Robert Penta]: And you're not.

[Robert Penta]: Why?

[Robert Penta]: My opinion, and it's election year.

[Robert Penta]: And you're getting all this confronted in front of you.

[Robert Penta]: You're gonna be getting sidewalks, you're gonna be getting streets, all done.

[Robert Penta]: But where was this money not being used during this past year?

[Robert Penta]: During a year which people had to suffer to go through this.

[Robert Penta]: Why should the fire department have to wait?

[Robert Penta]: on their turnaround gear that they were promised not only last year but the year before.

[Robert Penta]: And now all of a sudden it's found in a free cash supplement when it could have been at the same time taken out of free cash.

[Robert Penta]: It could have been taken out as of January 1st with the new administration.

[Robert Penta]: The politics behind this is quite obvious.

[Robert Penta]: But even more to the politics of it is tomorrow night.

[Robert Penta]: My suggestion would be to wait until tomorrow night, see what this address is all about.

[Robert Penta]: And if the address has inclusions of other transfers of money or monies that have to go out for the purposes of being bonded, I think you really need to have a discussion.

[Robert Penta]: And you, Mr. President, you know, amongst this council, there's $210,000 a year paid in salaries.

[Robert Penta]: The executive office, the mayor only gets paid $140,000 a year.

[Robert Penta]: So there's more power strength here by what you are getting paid than what that corner office is getting.

[Robert Penta]: And you should put that to use.

[Robert Penta]: And if four of you get together and saying, hey, before we start expending these monies, just right off the hat, Councilor Marks, you've asked for two years in a row for a truck division within the police department.

[Robert Penta]: Nowhere is that found here, and nowhere is it found in the capital improvement plan.

[Robert Penta]: Think about it, in today's day and age, you're talking about email now being in the fire department.

[Robert Penta]: I don't even know if they have email in the police department, but if the fire department is now getting email, and they're supposed to be technologically up to snuff here.

[Robert Penta]: We should have the gentleman who runs your computer system down here, and he should be questioned as to what are the problems, and what is the technology needed within this city of Medford, whether it be the fire department, school department, or the city.

[Robert Penta]: You haven't had that conversation.

[Robert Penta]: There's a wishlist that goes out every single year.

[Robert Penta]: The wishlist is never even addressed.

[Robert Penta]: You just got through, Mr. President, talking about the scanner to the OCD, I mean, excuse me, the engineering office asked for.

[Robert Penta]: It's a simple little request that could have come right out of free cash last year, two years ago.

[Robert Penta]: As a matter of fact, when the lady was there and she made her presentation before the council, she showed you emails that were sent, emails that were sent.

[Robert Penta]: that the administration wouldn't do it.

[Robert Penta]: So what's being obvious is the fact that you're being asked to do something tonight.

[Robert Penta]: That's not what I'm saying.

[Robert Penta]: What I'm saying is you have one more night to wait and see.

[Robert Penta]: I don't see this as being such an emergency that it needs to be voted on tonight.

[Robert Penta]: Your own council rule says the same thing.

[Robert Penta]: Lay it on the table for one week, and if it comes out to be the same when you want to vote for it, go right ahead.

[Robert Penta]: Pieces have been taken out of a capital improvement program.

[Robert Penta]: with its own campus provisos for the students, it's no interest of us.

[Robert Penta]: If in fact you get a document that gives you these locations of where these students are, I think it's incumbent

[Robert Penta]: for the purposes of enforcement and having your teeth on the landowner who's collecting the rent from that student to have that student who's going to Tufts University be one of the students that's sitting in an off-campus position.

[Robert Penta]: I think that could bring you to the compromise of saying, rather than having your code enforcement officer go out, it's upon the landowner.

[Robert Penta]: And once that landowner is found in violation, then the city has its own teeth.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think anybody of you were on the council at the time, but we can go back a few years ago, and I think Barbara will remember this, where there was a student living in the garage roof in a particular location off campus.

[Robert Penta]: And I think that there was a huge settlement, and to the hundreds and thousands of dollars, I believe to the family of the student, unfortunately, who died there, but it was the city's responsibility, or should have been the city's responsibility, if we follow this train of thought, that the location did not provide

[Robert Penta]: the safety and the security for that particular person.

[Robert Penta]: I offer that out as a compromise.

[Robert Penta]: And then it doesn't become a, a matter of public record.

[Robert Penta]: It becomes a matter of a public safety issue that the building department has the responsibility for.

[Robert Penta]: to hurt the taxpayers and the business people of this community.

[Robert Penta]: We've been told that seniors can park for nothing, but you have to pay $25 to park for nothing to get the permit for once a year.

[Robert Penta]: And you can't transfer it from one car to another, which, again, doesn't help a senior in that particular case.

[Robert Penta]: You can go down to Haines Square any time in the morning, and you can see just many, many more blank spaces than there have ever been before.

[Robert Penta]: Go to Medford Square in the morning, and the same situation happens.

[Robert Penta]: I think the problem here is that Park Medford is just not doing

[Robert Penta]: for the city as what the city thought it would do for its taxpayers and more importantly for its business people.

[Robert Penta]: So I would suggest when you folks have your Committee of the Whole next meeting, I think it would be more appropriate to have a subsequent meeting here before the council where all the taxpayers can hear and see what's going on.

[Robert Penta]: Because a lot of people can't come to a Committee of the Whole meeting or a subcommittee meeting for whatever you want to call it.

[Robert Penta]: This is their public forum.

[Robert Penta]: This is something that has an impact on the entire city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Every single business person and every single person that drives through this community has to be confronted with those stupid kiosks where you're supposed to go and pay, okay?

[Robert Penta]: with situations as Council Member O'Connor had.

[Robert Penta]: You had a lady who gave me her ticket, and she had 10 minutes left on her ticket, and she still got a parking violation.

[Robert Penta]: And having to go, having to go give up her time, having to take time off from work, which means it could possibly be paid, vacation time, what have you.

[Robert Penta]: This isn't right.

[Robert Penta]: And with the age of computer technology that we have here right now, if they can't resolve something that simple by going into the Park Medford office that can be resolved, this doesn't make any sense at all.

[Robert Penta]: I think it's an insult to the taxpayers and it's an insult to this council who unfortunately has to bear the burden of all these complaints because this is the situation that you're in right now.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta.

[Robert Penta]: I live at Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., a former member of this august body.

[Robert Penta]: In May of 2016, when this issue appeared itself before the council, I came and I spoke and I relayed information for which I will again

[Robert Penta]: reaffirm with you after speaking with Bond Council for the City of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: The City of Medford engages in a tax-exempt IRS status which provides for certain exemptions for the purposes of being excluded from tax for tax particular purposes.

[Robert Penta]: And there is a specific section on 2.2 called government bond status for which the City of Medford has three delineations for which it has a requirement for which it cannot engage in this type of a for-profit private business

[Robert Penta]: using a municipal piece of property, which would be for profit, even though some of the time would be allotted for the purposes of using the city.

[Robert Penta]: It's very specific in 2.2 of the section of the IRS tax exempt certificate, specifically for the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: It clearly states that a non-governmental person will be treated as using proceeds of the bonds and proceeds of each issue of prior obligation of the projects in one of three areas.

[Robert Penta]: One uses any portion of the projects as owner, lessee,

[Robert Penta]: service provider, operator, or manager, two, acquires the output of the projects, and four, section four, enters into any other arrangement that provided a special legal entitlement or special economic benefit to the non-governmental person.

[Robert Penta]: That would happen as what's being presented or potentially could have been presented.

[Robert Penta]: And accordingly, it says that the city will not enter in any contract or other arrangement after the closing date for the operation or management of any component

[Robert Penta]: of the project by any party other than a governmental unit in which the governmental unit is the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: The city of Medford has a tax certificate.

[Robert Penta]: It's an 11 page document.

[Robert Penta]: It specifically outlines subject matters such as this.

[Robert Penta]: Spoke to bond council last year, spoke to office again today, and there happens to be no re-interest in issuing this particular bond.

[Robert Penta]: Also, it has to have a legal review as required by the IRS on any exemption or exception.

[Robert Penta]: And I don't believe any exception has been offered to you by any legal writing or offering or request for one.

[Robert Penta]: And I would say at this point in time, uh, thank you for bringing it forward.

[Robert Penta]: Counsel Lungo and uh, thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta zero summit road, Medford mass, former member of this August body who did engage in a conversation as it relates to this.

[Robert Penta]: At that point in time, I was a member of the board of directors of the mass municipal association and I brought the message back to this method city council.

[Robert Penta]: as it related to the new changing of GIC insurance to cities and towns.

[Robert Penta]: Quick history.

[Robert Penta]: The reason why I'm here tonight, I was edified by a union representative as it states, as this gentleman stated that on February 1st, there will be a public hearing in Boston as it relates to these new GIC changes.

[Robert Penta]: And he was, he was encouraging his membership, which includes city of Medford employees to go there and to participate.

[Robert Penta]: Um,

[Robert Penta]: I'm speaking in behalf of all City of Medford employees and retirees, as well as myself, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: Quick history, back in January 14th of 2015, before this Medford City Council, it was shown and it was presented to you that GIC, for which the City of Medford became a member on January 1st, 2012,

[Robert Penta]: was at a deficit of approximately $160 to $190 million in deficit.

[Robert Penta]: And that was a result of three prior years of not being funded by the state legislature to meet the needs that GIC needed to have.

[Robert Penta]: That presented, at that point in time, a $120 million deficit that was below the, at present then, funding level.

[Robert Penta]: And that was due to the statewide underfunding, and it was also due to the misprojected increased claims costs

[Robert Penta]: regarding health care here in Massachusetts.

[Robert Penta]: So what happened at that point in time some two years ago?

[Robert Penta]: Rates increased, deductibles increased, and office visits increased.

[Robert Penta]: When the city of Medford went from bargaining from a PPO to a POS, for cities and towns required union support.

[Robert Penta]: And the union support came from the city of Medford as well when they signed that contract in August of 2011 by 14 signatories

[Robert Penta]: of people, representatives here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Now we have a GIC proposal that is pending before the legislature and it'll be pending before GIC.

[Robert Penta]: Strike that, it's before GIC, not the legislature.

[Robert Penta]: And the proposal is going to make a request that a unilateral

[Robert Penta]: implementation for an additional cost shift and plan design be proposed.

[Robert Penta]: We here in the city of Medford are under the GIC plan.

[Robert Penta]: And under the GIC plan, we agreed by subscription and definition and signatory signing off in August of 2011 that we would accept whatever GIC was going to present, whether they be for the cost, whether they be for the, for whatever the costs were,

[Robert Penta]: that people chose in their health plan.

[Robert Penta]: Now, if we go to this unilateral change, the question, and the question still hasn't been answered, and GIC has yet to answer it, does the unilateral change mean that the manager or the mayor of a community can unilaterally make that change, or do they need the confirmation support by the local legislative body?

[Robert Penta]: In this case, it would be the city council.

[Robert Penta]: That's what we had to do years ago when Mayor McGlynn accepted GIC.

[Robert Penta]: It was presented before the Medford City Council for a vote of support.

[Robert Penta]: Now, the ludicrous part about this whole thing is you're asked to vote on something, but you can't discuss it.

[Robert Penta]: That makes no sense at all.

[Robert Penta]: Absolutely no sense at all.

[Robert Penta]: And again, I don't know where you're going to be going, but I think those of you that aren't on GIC and have an opportunity to speak

[Robert Penta]: and make your representation known to the employees and the retirees of the city, this is going to be huge.

[Robert Penta]: And the reason why it's going to be huge, because the state's use of this increase is projected at approximately 3.6%.

[Robert Penta]: But it also provides that these costs are running at large because of MassHealth.

[Robert Penta]: MassHealth is a $14 billion item in the state's budget.

[Robert Penta]: It represents approximately

[Robert Penta]: 40% of the state's budget.

[Robert Penta]: And because it represents 40% of the state budget, whatever those cost overruns have been over the past two or three years, they are now being shifted over, as in the administration and finance report the other day came out and said that everyone's going to have to bear the cost.

[Robert Penta]: Well, I don't think everybody should have to bear the cost.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think an active working employee and more importantly a retiree should have to pay for that cost.

[Robert Penta]: They didn't cause that cost increase to take place.

[Robert Penta]: I think the legislature on Beacon Hill, they need to do their work and they need to get into reading what's going on.

[Robert Penta]: They need to understand that the cost of health care and drugs and prescriptions

[Robert Penta]: is huge here.

[Robert Penta]: We are the most expensive country in the world, and we are the most expensive state in the country as a result of health care costs.

[Robert Penta]: In January of 2017, this month, there was a Freedman health care report that came out that so describes the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

[Robert Penta]: in the position that it's in.

[Robert Penta]: We pay an awful lot for health care in Massachusetts.

[Robert Penta]: Yes, we do have probably the best hospitals in the world, but that should have nothing to do with how we in cities and towns went out of our way six years ago to negotiate our health care costs.

[Robert Penta]: As of January of this year, according to the contract and the memorandum of understanding between the city of Medford

[Robert Penta]: its retirees and its active employees, as of January this year, we have until January to October 1st to make a definite decision whether we stay in the GIC plan or not.

[Robert Penta]: And if we don't stay in that plan for GIC, we have between October 1st and June 30th of 2018 to make that final decision where we go, whether we go back to competitive bidding, other insurance companies come in and what have you.

[Robert Penta]: The contract that Mayor McGlynn signed brings us to 2018, that's six and a half years.

[Robert Penta]: The city of Medford was told we would be saving over that six and a half year period of time approximately 25 plus million dollars in health care costs and the rates that were set by GIC would be the rates that would be set for those people who are members of GIC.

[Robert Penta]: This change to go to a unilateral decision, if GIC were to accept it, and the city of Medford were to engage in a unilateral decision, could have an absolute financial devastating effect on retirees and active employees.

[Robert Penta]: That's not what it was meant to be.

[Robert Penta]: This proposal, unilaterally, is going to shift the cost

[Robert Penta]: to GIC employees, because if GIC employees go to a unilateral determination, those people who don't have GIC, as compared to those that do, will bear the additional cost as it relates to making the bill be paid here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: The other part we should take into consideration is the question, how do we get this question answered?

[Robert Penta]: You folks, those of you that are out there right now, that are not sitting here, but are members of GIC, I think you need to ask the question.

[Robert Penta]: because it's not expressing a financial interest, it's expressing a need to know whether in fact the city of Medford is going to continue on with GIC.

[Robert Penta]: And if the city of Medford is not going to continue on with GIC, you as a legislative body, I'm assuming we'll have to make that decision by choice of change.

[Robert Penta]: And the mayor should be making this type of representation before you, this type of consideration before you as to where and what effect it's going to have here within your budget.

[Robert Penta]: Let's see.

[Robert Penta]: Okay.

[Robert Penta]: This brings us to the matter of how do we pursue section 13, 14, and 15 and the memorandum of agreement between the city of Medford and its retirees and

[Robert Penta]: and it's retirees and everyday workers, regular workers.

[Robert Penta]: These action alerts coming from the Commonwealth of Mass, coming from the Office of Administration and Finance, participating municipalities such as we, and the memorandum of understanding that we have over here, it's very important, it's very important to know.

[Robert Penta]: And it's very important to understand that by June 30th of 2018, you folks are gonna have to know where you're gonna go.

[Robert Penta]: But it's the retirees,

[Robert Penta]: who are the important component of all of this.

[Robert Penta]: Because they should not have the shifted burden of having the increase in cost for medical services through the insurance company for which they are represented by people who negotiate here with the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: You know, we talk about a lot of things around here.

[Robert Penta]: But this is equally as important as maybe to zoning, because we're talking about our municipal employees, we're talking about our school department employees, we're talking about union and non-union members, because they all come under this insurance situation.

[Robert Penta]: But when you think about the increase in cost, your cost in your food, your cost in your taxes that just went up, your water and sewer rates that have just gone up, you have a Community Preservation Act tax that went up, okay?

[Robert Penta]: All types of insurances that have gone up.

[Robert Penta]: And most recently, since January 11, you have people concerned over whether their employment as it relates to vacation time was going to be an issue.

[Robert Penta]: That's gone back and forth as to what it's all about.

[Robert Penta]: It's making it harder and harder for our municipal employees.

[Robert Penta]: They don't make an awful lot of money.

[Robert Penta]: They work for their job.

[Robert Penta]: They're good employees.

[Robert Penta]: 99% of them are good employees.

[Robert Penta]: But they have a right to know where they're going and to shop around, if need be the case, to pick out a health care provider.

[Robert Penta]: But the city owes it to every single municipal employee and retiree to let them know whether they're going to be on board or not.

[Robert Penta]: whether the unilateral proposal, if approved by GIC, empowers the mayor of this community to make independent decisions, that for which GIC, for which we are presently under, would not, I mean, that's the whole issue.

[Robert Penta]: February 1st, there's a huge hearing.

[Robert Penta]: It goes into all the issues.

[Robert Penta]: Yes, no, we're different.

[Robert Penta]: You cannot.

[Robert Penta]: There's a story regarding a young man.

[Robert Penta]: His name is DJ Simons.

[Robert Penta]: He's a Boston police officer, 28 years old.

[Robert Penta]: He is the unsung hero.

[Robert Penta]: He is the forgotten man in the Boston Marathon story.

[Robert Penta]: And what I would like to propose and ask you as Medford City Councilors to do on behalf of our city, knowing that we have that great monument out there for the Crystal Campbell Peace Garden,

[Robert Penta]: that represents our city, who recognizes in times of tragedy, we do stand to the occasion.

[Robert Penta]: We put our political principles aside, and we do unify amongst ourselves.

[Robert Penta]: This gentleman, 28 years old, was hit by a bomb, pipe bomb, four days after the incident that took place at the Boston Marathon.

[Robert Penta]: He was one of the first officers on the scene.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that, he received a head injury.

[Robert Penta]: And he died subsequently one year later.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that,

[Robert Penta]: His mother, Roxanne Simons, and father, who lived down in the Cape, were never notified of this story called Patriots Day.

[Robert Penta]: They called up the producers, Peter Berg, Mark Wahlberg, and they have yet to receive a response.

[Robert Penta]: A state representative up on Beacon Hill named Tim Whelan

[Robert Penta]: made an application to the, um, the board of the directors and the film director, uh, for, uh, Patriot's day and asked them if they would consider doing a post script somehow of putting it in there.

[Robert Penta]: Never got a response back.

[Robert Penta]: The part that was hurting and disturbing according to Mrs. Simons is the fact that when they can't at the end of the movie, the postscripts of the movie had the four pitches and the four names of the folks that we have in our peace garden.

[Robert Penta]: But Mr. Simon's name was, was not there.

[Robert Penta]: This gentleman is 28 years old.

[Robert Penta]: He's a college graduate.

[Robert Penta]: And subsequently, on graduating college, he went to the Boston Police School to become a Boston police officer.

[Robert Penta]: He was originally stationed in Brighton, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: But he was more of wanting to be not a Boston police officer who hands out tickets.

[Robert Penta]: He wanted to get into the inner city youth, and that's where he did.

[Robert Penta]: He went into the inner city youth where the problems were, and he loved it.

[Robert Penta]: He was a good police officer, loved by many policemen, and loved by his community.

[Robert Penta]: He unfortunately has not even received any kind of recognition throughout this whole program called Patriot's Day, which is a great movie if you want to look at it like that.

[Robert Penta]: And as they do say, sometimes there are some errors and there's some slips to get through.

[Robert Penta]: But they were notified well in advance, and they're still notified as of now, that maybe to have him recognized as being an unsung hero who died, unfortunately, one year after the tragedy.

[Robert Penta]: He was one of the first people, one of the first people

[Robert Penta]: of Boston police responders to Watertown Mass on the night of that incident.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, all my council colleagues, you folks do many resolutions for many people, whether they are for sports, whether they are for someone who might have passed away, whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: But for the family of this police officer, I think it would be outstanding that this Medford City Council recognizes the fact that this gentleman, DJ Simons,

[Robert Penta]: who didn't get recognized, is recognized by the city of Medford, its city government.

[Robert Penta]: For the gentleman did give his life.

[Robert Penta]: He did respond and he was there.

[Robert Penta]: And for his parents not to have any recognition to that at all, it's just not right.

[Robert Penta]: And I don't think it's fair.

[Robert Penta]: So I ask of you, seven of you collectively, for one of you to offer the resolution, or if jointly, to send a note of condolences and of appreciation and of thanks to the Simons family, thanking them for their sons.

[Robert Penta]: efforts as a result of the Boston Marathon.

[Robert Penta]: And maybe there is something, somehow, some way, a plaque of postscript can find its way to that Peace Garden as well here in the city of Medford to let the entire world, to let the entire people know and to let the Simons family know that the city of Medford will not forget and they're most appreciative of what their son did.

[Robert Penta]: So I offer, I ask one of you to come forward and do that.

[Robert Penta]: Mayor Marty Walsh of Boston, as of today's paper,

[Robert Penta]: has he himself has taken it upon himself to seek out through the producers and the directors of that show who have refused, I shouldn't say refused, who have yet to respond back to him to have him included.

[Robert Penta]: What the reason is, nobody knows.

[Robert Penta]: Yale Street parking lot, people in the lot after six o'clock at night.

[Robert Penta]: giving out tickets.

[Robert Penta]: Other parts of the city, the new people that have come on board with this new company, and I don't know who they are because you guys don't have a contract, you should have a copy of the contract as amended, should indicate that these folks should be aware as to what they're doing.

[Robert Penta]: Also, the fact that you can't go out there, these folks are supposed to be identified with a tag on them, with a face on their ID card, so to speak, and not something that's hidden behind their jacket or what have you.

[Robert Penta]: and I think.

[Robert Penta]: The other thing, and it's a concern, it's a bone of contention that I've had since day one, we were told during the last mayoral campaign by this mayor that seniors would be able to park for nothing.

[Robert Penta]: What you have now is if a senior wants to park in the city, that senior has to pay $25 to have the opportunity to park for nothing.

[Robert Penta]: They get a card or whatever it might be, and they can't transfer it to another car, because if you're a senior, and you happen to be 65, that's what they use for a standard, and 62 is social security age,

[Robert Penta]: So why it's 65 to be a senior, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: But if you get this little placard or whatever it might be, or sticker, you can't transfer it to another car.

[Robert Penta]: So if you're a senior driving in the city and your car is either broken down and you wanna use another car, because you are a senior, you should be able to do it.

[Robert Penta]: So the requirement doesn't go to the senior, apparently it goes to the car and you're stuck to that particular car.

[Robert Penta]: I think that really needs to be reviewed and looked upon.

[Robert Penta]: But more importantly, I just think the statistical analysis should be forthcoming

[Robert Penta]: You folks had asked for a monthly basis.

[Robert Penta]: The last time you got it was eight months into the, nine months into the year.

[Robert Penta]: It just doesn't seem right.

[Robert Penta]: My suggestion would be to have you have the new people, just like you had a Republic when they first come in, have them come and appear before the council.

[Robert Penta]: Air your differences with them.

[Robert Penta]: Let them explain to you.

[Robert Penta]: Let them explain to the public what the changes might be.

[Robert Penta]: You know, it's kind of hard, you know, when people call up and they ask, you know, what can we do?

[Robert Penta]: How do we make this thing better?

[Robert Penta]: Lady comes to city hall.

[Robert Penta]: thinking that she can pay her ticket here.

[Robert Penta]: She can't.

[Robert Penta]: And while she's here trying to pay the ticket, she's outside and she's getting a ticket on her car.

[Robert Penta]: And she's coming in here thinking this is the way you're supposed to pay the ticket.

[Robert Penta]: You go down the street to go to pay the ticket.

[Robert Penta]: And then, oh, too bad, you can't.

[Robert Penta]: You've got a ticket.

[Robert Penta]: You stayed here too long.

[Robert Penta]: There's a whole host of issues that are still

[Robert Penta]: surrounding this whole thing.

[Robert Penta]: They're into the neighborhoods, where resident parking takes place, and late at night.

[Robert Penta]: These things are just multiplying, and nothing seems to be getting better.

[Robert Penta]: And if you speak to some of the business people in the square, in all the squares, they'll basically tell you that there are more spots open now than there were before.

[Robert Penta]: That's great, but their business isn't getting any much better than it was before.

[Robert Penta]: If anything, it's getting less.

[Robert Penta]: So the only reprieve that was really given during this past year is when the mayor was in, Mayor McGlynn was here,

[Robert Penta]: And I guess he worked out a deal with Republic at that time, during the holidays, from November 4th to, I believe, January 3rd, that on the weekends, you didn't have to pay to use the meters.

[Robert Penta]: But that seems to be something that's not being worked out right now by this company.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know what they're going to do for the holidays this year.

[Robert Penta]: It's a new company.

[Robert Penta]: They're new in town.

[Robert Penta]: But I strongly suggest that you have them before you, rather than having these piecemeal approaches of people with concerns and complaints, because you really need to take a look at the contract.

[Robert Penta]: You really need to know what they're doing in this community.

[Robert Penta]: And Councilor Lungo-Koehn is right, asking for that because I think the time is near.

[Robert Penta]: Your holidays are right around the corner.

[Robert Penta]: President's administration says it would be a minimum of seven years out.

[Robert Penta]: But we can't find the money to take care, unfortunately, the people.

[Robert Penta]: who work on a daily basis, once a year or twice a year, depending on the primary and the final elections that take place.

[Robert Penta]: You know, I think it's a service, minimal as it might be, that they deserve something having.
