[Robert Penta]: which has been on the council agenda for many years, of looking at a new fire station on Riverside Avenue and possibly looking at a satellite fire station that sits on the opposite side of Wellington Station, where the station landing is, where the new development of 200 more units are going up, which are right opposite the Wellington Station, plus the whole commercial industrial area over there.

[Robert Penta]: And I think that's something that really needs to be addressed, over and beyond the fact that if you look at your budget,

[Robert Penta]: In this year's budget, your fire department overtime money was there.

[Robert Penta]: But once again, on the annual basis, on the police department side, their overtime money wasn't there.

[Robert Penta]: It has to be transferred each and every year.

[Robert Penta]: Now that's a serious question to ask, because they range anywhere from $400,000 to $600,000 a year in overtime, where the fire department has their money in overtime built right in.

[Robert Penta]: Why that happens in the police department, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: But if you want a true and accurate accounting of what overtime costs,

[Robert Penta]: or projected overtime costs, that money should be definitive right in there.

[Robert Penta]: It's understaffed, and you don't have the right equipment to do all the jobs that are necessary on a daily basis.

[Robert Penta]: Right now, you're dealing with an interim temporary supervisor, a director of the building over there.

[Robert Penta]: I just don't know where it's going.

[Robert Penta]: And a lot of this click it, fix it idea of what are being asked to be fixed,

[Robert Penta]: are being mocked off as being completed, and they haven't even been addressed, they haven't even been resolved.

[Robert Penta]: If somebody's making a mistake or it's an error, for whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: and we were doing High Street, and the MWRA was in here putting in new water lines, especially at the intersection of Governor's Avenue and High Street, there was a project cost in that particular area of quite a few dollars.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penter.

[Robert Penta]: When that decision was rendered this morning, I took all afternoon to review it, page by page, word by word.

[Robert Penta]: Fourteen pages of a hastily written decision because

[Robert Penta]: The board, I believe, did not want to hear what this Medford City Council wanted to do.

[Robert Penta]: And the city solicitor is absolutely right, because I've checked the cases and other cases that reflect upon the fact.

[Robert Penta]: You folks, you are the master of the zoning of this city of Medford, not the board of appeals, because that's what they are.

[Robert Penta]: People go to them on an appeal.

[Robert Penta]: But you folks, you write the zoning.

[Robert Penta]: The zoning begins and ends here, goes through whatever the process might be.

[Robert Penta]: So you have every right to not only appeal this decision,

[Robert Penta]: but to appeal it as loudly and as strongly as you can.

[Robert Penta]: On page five of the decision, the commentary says it completes the zoning, the industrial zoning, except for heightened use.

[Robert Penta]: Now, this is an industrial piece of property, which is allowed to have certain exemptions that you don't have.

[Robert Penta]: But the heightened use relegates itself to the multiple dwelling portion.

[Robert Penta]: We can go back to 1988.

[Robert Penta]: There was a company called Asano and White.

[Robert Penta]: They did a, I think it was a $70,000, $80,000 report here in the city of Medford as it reflects upon housing, development, traffic impact, and water and sewer.

[Robert Penta]: And the Wellington Glenwood area was one of the particular areas that they did it on.

[Robert Penta]: And Councilman Marks alluded to the fact on page eight, the topography of the land.

[Robert Penta]: The board says that a substantial part of the property, if it's not developed with multiple dwelling,

[Robert Penta]: In the ordinance, the industrial zone, in essence, will become inoperative because it'll just stay industrial and you can't do anything with it.

[Robert Penta]: I think there's one point that hasn't been said thus far, unless somebody else wants to say it later on.

[Robert Penta]: Don't forget, when these folks came on March 31st and before that, they didn't say no to the development.

[Robert Penta]: They were conciliatory.

[Robert Penta]: They said, reduce the size of the project, make it smaller if you can, and I think the people could live with it.

[Robert Penta]: But that didn't take place.

[Robert Penta]: It's kind of interesting, that decision.

[Robert Penta]: It says the following, in conclusion, the board is hopeful that the developer will reconsider the size and scope of the proposed apartment building.

[Robert Penta]: There is much to commend the overall project in such close proximity to public transportation

[Robert Penta]: including the commuter rail.

[Robert Penta]: Now, in that decision, they talked about the abutters that showed up.

[Robert Penta]: In this 14-page decision, there's nothing about an abutter that showed up, nothing about the concerns that they had.

[Robert Penta]: All they talked about was the fact that this is going to be great for that particular area.

[Robert Penta]: April 27th of this year, Mayor Burke of this community said this is a great project to develop a new neighborhood in this part of town.

[Robert Penta]: We're excited about it.

[Robert Penta]: But where is the transparency, the open public meeting on zoning of this nature?

[Robert Penta]: Because you folks have never had a development this large smack you in the face.

[Robert Penta]: And since you've all been here, you've never had an audience like this who are so upset over the fact that they weren't a part of it.

[Robert Penta]: They're coming in after the fact.

[Robert Penta]: They should have been here before the fact, before this honorable body.

[Robert Penta]: You folks wrote the law, and you should be well aware of what's going on upstairs in that Board of Appeals.

[Robert Penta]: You know, in the decision, it's relegated to the terms.

[Robert Penta]: They state the following.

[Robert Penta]: We respect the fact that this zoning and site plan review fits the standards of this particular project.

[Robert Penta]: This is the wording of the zoning and the site plan review.

[Robert Penta]: The purpose of our zoning is to promote the health, safety, morals, convenience, and to lessen the danger from congestion and confusion.

[Robert Penta]: Site plan review states the following.

[Robert Penta]: The purpose of this article is to promote development, which is harmonious with surrounding areas and adequate consideration of abutting land owners.

[Robert Penta]: Well, we have abutting land owners here tonight.

[Robert Penta]: Where were their concerns is written in this document.

[Robert Penta]: It's nowhere to be found.

[Robert Penta]: And if it's nowhere to be found here, it's quite obvious that they didn't take it into consideration.

[Robert Penta]: And that was only four stories high and for 30 units.

[Robert Penta]: This is 490 units high, 490 units and five stories high.

[Robert Penta]: Big difference.

[Robert Penta]: What are you going to have here for the bottom line?

[Robert Penta]: Because it's the impact that's going to affect the neighborhood.

[Robert Penta]: This is what you're going to have.

[Robert Penta]: If everybody's online and all the developments are coming on board.

[Robert Penta]: You'll have Coles, you'll have Marshalls, you'll have Wegmans, you'll have Lumineer.

[Robert Penta]: They just sold their building after one year for $66.6 million.

[Robert Penta]: What makes you think these people may not do the same thing?

[Robert Penta]: Come in.

[Robert Penta]: Hi, Hawaii.

[Robert Penta]: See you later.

[Robert Penta]: Make a fast buck.

[Robert Penta]: Who pays for it?

[Robert Penta]: The neighborhood.

[Robert Penta]: Then you're going to have the skating rink over there.

[Robert Penta]: Then you're going to have the 490 units.

[Robert Penta]: Then you're going to have eight commercial businesses, three apartment buildings.

[Robert Penta]: And now let's take a ride down Locust Street and bang a left and go to Wellington Circle.

[Robert Penta]: You're going to have 200 more units of apartment housing going over there.

[Robert Penta]: And don't forget the casino when that opens up.

[Robert Penta]: You put this all together.

[Robert Penta]: And you take Little Locust Street, which is a two-way street, it's going to make no sense at all.

[Robert Penta]: If this administration had any brains, they would have called you into that office over there, sat down with you and said, what do you think, guys?

[Robert Penta]: This is what I think I'd like to see.

[Robert Penta]: Can we add or subtract to it and come up with a unified front?

[Robert Penta]: No, you have an administration that just goes on their own way and now you're here to pick up the slack.

[Robert Penta]: And what's the slack?

[Robert Penta]: You're going to have to take money and appeal it on behalf of the taxpayers.

[Robert Penta]: And I would expect you folks, do appeal it and do spend that money and send the message back to that office over there that you guys and gals are not patsies for someone else's administration when you're not even brought in and consulted.

[Robert Penta]: There is no transparency to what's going on in this city right now.

[Robert Penta]: And this is the perfect example when you look at a development such as this.

[Robert Penta]: This should never be happened without your consideration and consultation.

[Robert Penta]: You know, we get elected for one reason, or I got elected for one reason when I was on that side of the rail, to do the people's business.

[Robert Penta]: not to sit here and wonder what I'm supposed to do.

[Robert Penta]: If you're brand new, it's a learning process, then you better learn real quick.

[Robert Penta]: Because you know what you're dealing with?

[Robert Penta]: You're dealing with the taxpayers' money.

[Robert Penta]: You're dealing with their direction in how this city is supposed to go forward, whether it's on the school department side when you take that final vote, or whether it's on the city side when you're putting all your money together to find out in what direction are we going to be able to go.

[Robert Penta]: Now, you have a budget coming up right now.

[Robert Penta]: And in this particular budget, as the councilor, Mr. Rumley alluded to, you should make the request tonight to put a minimum of $50,000 in there.

[Robert Penta]: And I'm going to tell you the reason why.

[Robert Penta]: A few years ago, when I was on this city council, we had a decision to be made regarding Tufts University on a piece of land that they wanted to take and they wanted to use it.

[Robert Penta]: I think it was Foley, Holg, Elliott and Boston.

[Robert Penta]: I think it was a hundred thousand dollars would cost the city, but the city won its case.

[Robert Penta]: Okay.

[Robert Penta]: because the council was determined when they took that vote that we weren't going to get pushed around and we weren't going to have the Dover Amendment used against us because it was inappropriate at that particular time.

[Robert Penta]: I think it was 1991 or whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: But you've got to be realistic about this.

[Robert Penta]: You've got to move ASAP.

[Robert Penta]: Plus another thing, Mr. Rumley, you can correct me if I'm wrong.

[Robert Penta]: If you guys and girls are going to come on board and appeal this case, you can ask for an extension of time.

[Robert Penta]: Same thing that the visiting nurses did.

[Robert Penta]: I believe they got a six-month extension of time when the taxpayers decided or the abutters decided to appeal this particular case.

[Robert Penta]: In 1985, I made an offer of a resolution before this Method City Council.

[Robert Penta]: None of you were on it.

[Robert Penta]: That's why I'm still here, because I remember these things.

[Robert Penta]: I got a bag full of tricks.

[Robert Penta]: that tells me what to remember every single time, okay?

[Robert Penta]: I made a resolution to put a moratorium on building and construction in the city of Medford because at that point in time, you had high-rise condominiums going up with no rhyme and no reason.

[Robert Penta]: And if you didn't take a look and see where you wanted your city to go and the traffic impact it would have, the social impact, the educational impact.

[Robert Penta]: And the educational impact, you would have no idea where you're going.

[Robert Penta]: And then again in 2005, I filed the same resolution.

[Robert Penta]: Miffitt City Council in both times approved it, and both times the city administration did not want to embark upon it.

[Robert Penta]: You know, it sounds nice to say, if this development takes place, I think we're going to get, here it goes, we're going to get approximately $1.5 million in building permits.

[Robert Penta]: We're going to get approximately $2 million in linkage.

[Robert Penta]: We're going to get approximately $1.375,000 in tax money.

[Robert Penta]: You know, money just for the sake of money should not make this city drive itself.

[Robert Penta]: You know what should drive this community?

[Robert Penta]: The heart of every single person in here.

[Robert Penta]: How you can get along, how you can live together, how your streets can be compatible, how your schools, your churches, and your neighbors can be compatible.

[Robert Penta]: Not to have a group of people come in here tonight, frustrated over the fact this is after the fact, and now you're picking up the ball and going forward.

[Robert Penta]: This should not be.

[Robert Penta]: They should be coming here tonight congratulating you because you stopped it early on and it came before you at an appropriate time.

[Robert Penta]: I hope this is a warning, Mr. President, and all members of the council, that you go forward, hire the attorney, and I'm quite sure that you will win.

[Robert Penta]: Absolutely.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: And I'd just like to say, and I brought this up about two or three weeks ago,

[Robert Penta]: regarding the bubble.

[Robert Penta]: There's a bond council that wrote the bond proposal.

[Robert Penta]: If you think of this thing logically and you think it through, you're allowing a private for-profit business to come in and take advantage of a city's bond at the city's interest rate and for them to make a profit on city time, on city property.

[Robert Penta]: Well, if we're going to do that, are we opening up Pandora's box to the swimming pool?

[Robert Penta]: Are we opening up to the skating rink?

[Robert Penta]: Are we opening up to the new $14.5 million science labs that we have in the school?

[Robert Penta]: Anything that we've had a bond that can have an effect upon the people within this community, we are now saying, come on in, pay us for what you think you want to pay us, and we'll entertain it if not accept it.

[Robert Penta]: You know, Councilman Marks made an interesting comment a few weeks ago when we had this discussion as it relates to it.

[Robert Penta]: If they're putting so much time into the bubble, I wish they would put more time into the educational process.

[Robert Penta]: at the school.

[Robert Penta]: They put a lot of time into hiring 5,000 administrators at over $95,000 a piece.

[Robert Penta]: And as a matter of fact, one of them was one who was terminated from one school, but hired back up at the high school at $95,000.

[Robert Penta]: A lot of interest, a lot of input went into that.

[Robert Penta]: But when we look at this, you have a definitely, you have a legal question here.

[Robert Penta]: And I think this council voted, all seven of you voted to have a report back from the bond council.

[Robert Penta]: From the bond counsel who wrote this for the city of Medford, the legal question is, can the city of Medford rent or lease this piece of property to a private for-profit company and then charge back the city of Medford for its use of the same property that they have leased for a measly $75,000 a year?

[Robert Penta]: Because that's all they give in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And don't forget, if you're right, Councilor Marks, if it's a 10-year deal and the city gets the bond,

[Robert Penta]: It's not costing these people anything, because they will write this off on a tax write-off for 10 years for its use, especially if it's a for-profit business.

[Robert Penta]: And what are we going to get at the very end as a community?

[Robert Penta]: Whatever the repairs that are needed to take place are going to take place, and who's going to have to pay for the city?

[Robert Penta]: These are the type of questions that would be great ballot questions to put out there during a general election.

[Robert Penta]: Because if it's such a wonderful argument and a wonderful issue, the pros and cons of public hearings

[Robert Penta]: and meetings at city council and at school committee meetings would serve the purpose of whether the people want this or not.

[Robert Penta]: I think if I had a student up at the high school right now, I would be more concerned on the educational quality of where that student needs to go or would like to go rather than arguing over a bubble that might have some not only logistical, legal questions, but would have questions over the fact that what are we doing?

[Robert Penta]: Taxpayers' money.

[Robert Penta]: When we as members of the Medford City Council voted for the science labs,

[Robert Penta]: for the skating rink, for the swimming pool, and Edgeley Field.

[Robert Penta]: We were taking the taxpayers of Medford's money and the bond rating that we were getting at that particular time to purchase that piece of bond in behalf of the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: You're not doing that now because what you're doing is you're abdicating the responsibility of the bond responsibility by the city and you're allowing an outside for-profit business to come in here, take advantage of it,

[Robert Penta]: and pay the city a measly $75 an hour, $75,000 a year, while at the same time make thousands and hundreds and thousands of dollars over the life of the bubble.

[Robert Penta]: That's not good financing.

[Robert Penta]: That doesn't make good sense to me.

[Robert Penta]: And I think this needs a lot more attention to the fact that you need all the legal questions asked.

[Robert Penta]: And I think you really need to compare this with this upcoming budget in the school department.

[Robert Penta]: It makes a huge difference as it relates to where priorities are going.

[Robert Penta]: We just got through talking about public safety, policemen.

[Robert Penta]: We talked about a new police station.

[Robert Penta]: Well, you're talking now about a bubble.

[Robert Penta]: And before the bubble bursts on the city of Medford and you get stuck with a financial boondoggle, I think we need to say, let's slow down and let's really take a look and see what's going on, because that's what this is all about.

[Robert Penta]: It's your money.

[Robert Penta]: It's our money.

[Robert Penta]: It's the city's money.

[Robert Penta]: It's everybody's money.

[Robert Penta]: And if we're going to allow a private for-profit business to come in and take advantage of our community and our real estate to the detriment of our city, for a measly $75,000, then you're really selling yourself short, and you're selling the taxpayers short.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penter.

[Robert Penta]: I live at Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: I'm a member of the Saugus party.

[Robert Penta]: My take on this is just a little bit different.

[Robert Penta]: We can talk about the maintenance, and it's quite obvious that the maintenance is an issue.

[Robert Penta]: But I'd like to get into the legality of the bond in and of itself.

[Robert Penta]: When the city of Medford went out for the bond in this particular field,

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, my purpose of saying the legality of it is because I would like to ask a question, and I think it needs to be answered.

[Robert Penta]: The question is very simple.

[Robert Penta]: The City of Medford owns the property.

[Robert Penta]: Now, will the City of Medford own the dome that the renter wants to come in?

[Robert Penta]: And if that's the situation, I think it changes the whole intent of what the City of Medford's bond was all about.

[Robert Penta]: and that bond being for the exclusive use, again, of the fields, Medford folks and students first, and however the rentals take place.

[Robert Penta]: But you're now building a bond, and now you want to build a bubble, and the bubble will declare an ownership of authority of the person that has it, and the city of Medford will not have priority of the use of those fields.

[Robert Penta]: So I would hope one of you folks on the council would make that request to our city solicitor to ask him

[Robert Penta]: if in fact this is even legal to do and what authority, if anything, does the city or will they have over the dome itself for the purposes of liability and for the purposes of its use?

[Robert Penta]: I think it's an important question to ask.

[Robert Penta]: I have no problem with the bubble, whether it goes or doesn't go.

[Robert Penta]: I think you need to have this legal question as it relates to this particular matter.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: So I would hope somebody.

[Robert Penta]: I'm trying to clarify the motion, if you'd give me the courtesy.

[Robert Penta]: Also, the fact of the matter is, does this interfere with the bond that originally was written, therefore allowing, as such right now, the city of Medford entertaining a private entity to come in, use its field for its particular purpose, the dome?

[Robert Penta]: I think that question needs to be asked.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: And you can review that on tape, if you'd like.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Pentez, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Robert Penta]: I'm a member of this board.

[Robert Penta]: Good evening, Mr. President and council members.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penta, Xero, Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: I'm a member of this board.

[Robert Penta]: I thank Mr. Capucci for coming forward because his flavor on the subject matter is different than mine.

[Robert Penta]: Mine basically as history has a way of repeating itself.

[Robert Penta]: Regarding public access here in the city of Medford, we are at the repeating stage once again.

[Robert Penta]: Since early 2013 to date, we, the Comcast and Verizon cable subscribers, have been charged the monthly public access fee totaling some $500,000.

[Robert Penta]: And we, the subscribers, still have no public access station.

[Robert Penta]: What we heard from 2013 by the city administration was that the city will be asking for

[Robert Penta]: Channel 3 records, bank statements, meeting minutes, and an inventory accounting of the Channel 3 Public Access Corporation, because then at that point in time, Channel 3 Corporation was filing for dissolution of its Chapter 3 Corporation.

[Robert Penta]: Records of expenditures of gasoline, restaurants, retail, supermarkets, hardware home suppliers, plumbing and air conditioning materials, building materials, auto supplies,

[Robert Penta]: Miscellaneous expenses in bank and ATM withdrawals, along with deposits and credits from the banks in the accounting were examples that were supposed to have been forwarded to the city of Medford pursuant to the dissolution filing.

[Robert Penta]: As of this date, no accounting of any records, bank statements, meeting minutes, or accurate inventory accounting has ever been verified from channel three.

[Robert Penta]: Regarding the city's lack of providing public access TV,

[Robert Penta]: The ever-going question since 2013 has been, why has the city failed to mandate that public access be made available as contractually applied for?

[Robert Penta]: Fast forward to today, and putting aside all the comments and issue regarding the forced ascertainment hearing, the former mayor's commission report regarding public cable access, and multiple council resolutions regarding this matter.

[Robert Penta]: It seems that this administration feels that to spend some $500,000 for an access studio up in the back of Medford High School will serve in the best interest of a local public access station.

[Robert Penta]: I don't believe this to be in the best interest of our subscribers and citizens, and for the following reasons.

[Robert Penta]: It's location, location, location that is the primary success staple of any business.

[Robert Penta]: The Medford High location will not serve the best interest for our public access.

[Robert Penta]: Examples as to why.

[Robert Penta]: Its public access is not on a main street that is centrally located.

[Robert Penta]: The entranceway is not well lit.

[Robert Penta]: It is not easily accessible to walk up and to walk back the hill from the back to and from Medford High School.

[Robert Penta]: It presents a winter problem of ice and snow needing to be cleared at all times on the hill and the walkway to the school's back entrance.

[Robert Penta]: It presents a safety security problem for after school hours

[Robert Penta]: and nighttime lighting is at a minimum.

[Robert Penta]: As a major positive contrast to the Medford High location, the Medford Public Library serves as the best location for public access studio.

[Robert Penta]: It is centrally located within our city.

[Robert Penta]: It has walking convenience within the city's downtown area and bus routes.

[Robert Penta]: It is handicap accessible to being easily available for front door entrance for bus and cab transportation.

[Robert Penta]: It offers a great additional public educational opportunity for community public access.

[Robert Penta]: Medford's $500,000 bank deposits from Comcast and Verizon thus far will definitely produce at the library the space needs necessary for this development.

[Robert Penta]: As Councilor Caraviello has indicated by requesting the Massachusetts State Library Commission come to Medford to ascertain what state additional funding can be for the library to Ghana for the library's rehabilitation,

[Robert Penta]: That, along with what I proposed last year during the Mayor's campaign to have a complaint present use and future use, along with the $500,000 funds that are readily available right now here in City Hall, could catapult the Medford Public Library to being Medford's premier central educational and social meeting spot that incorporates an entire community of opportunity.

[Robert Penta]: This would be the perfect segue for having

[Robert Penta]: The Massachusetts State Library Commission realized that we are working to make our library a major focal point in our city, and their additional support position would certainly carry us to that potential.

[Robert Penta]: It would be an example of how a city fully realizes the community potential of its public library.

[Robert Penta]: To my understanding and education thus far, this would be a first for the Massachusetts State Library Commission to co-invest with a city with matching funds.

[Robert Penta]: The Medford Vocational School location, as is presently being entertained, could be a satellite location for students' learning of production and access operations as a school program offering separate and distinct from the public access studio.

[Robert Penta]: This opportunity for community public access to be better located and more readily available should not be squandered away because of political posturing.

[Robert Penta]: Mayor McGlynn's own committee report of June 2015 specifically stated,

[Robert Penta]: We are a committee that feels that the best location will be in one that is conveniently and centrally located with its own entrance and exit and should be handicap accessible.

[Robert Penta]: The Method Public Library could serve no better location than the one that has been advised for.

[Robert Penta]: Also, with the city owning the property, annual rental payments will not have to be provided.

[Robert Penta]: Therefore, providing for more revenue to maintain, upgrade equipment,

[Robert Penta]: and conveniently offer to the community programs that showcase our city and the families and subscribers that watch and use public access TV.

[Robert Penta]: for paying for their public access.

[Robert Penta]: It's a lot of money and I think it offers a great opportunity.

[Robert Penta]: You've had other financial issues brought up, but you haven't had the issues of the senior citizen parking.

[Robert Penta]: It's separate and distinct unto itself.

[Robert Penta]: I beg to disagree with you, Council President DelaRosa.

[Robert Penta]: There's nothing in the records that even reflect that.

[Robert Penta]: I'm making that as a public request right now to have that as part of the official agenda when you folks meet.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Pater.

[Robert Penta]: I live at Zero Summit Road, a former member of the Zargas Party.

[Robert Penta]: First of all, to answer your question, Councilor De La Ruzo, Council President De La Ruzo, the Board of Appeals received a letter from Tufts University through their developers that they have rejected, and they're not going forward with the purchase of the sale of the piece of property.

[Robert Penta]: And I would hope it's because at the board of appeals meeting on the night that it took place, there wasn't one person that was there for it from the neighborhood.

[Robert Penta]: As a matter of fact, they were all against it.

[Robert Penta]: That's number one.

[Robert Penta]: Number two, I think the city of Medford has a responsibility.

[Robert Penta]: If in fact they do believe in keeping its history and a piece of its history, here's a classic opportunity for them to engage in this particular part.

[Robert Penta]: The method historical commission only has $700 a year in its budget.

[Robert Penta]: It's a pittance as compared to what the value of properties are here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And right around the corner, with the demolition delay permit hanging on them, you have another piece of property.

[Robert Penta]: It's called the Cabernet House.

[Robert Penta]: It's a French colony house.

[Robert Penta]: It's who owns the property.

[Robert Penta]: At Tufts University, with a billion-dollar endowment, not a million or a hundred million, a billion-dollar endowment, there is no need right now for them to have this piece of property to be sold.

[Robert Penta]: Now, they're getting a little bit tricky with this, because what they're trying to do is sell the property last week on Zillow, advertising it, and then they subsequently changed the language, not to say that it could be subdivided.

[Robert Penta]: It's just a single-house piece of property.

[Robert Penta]: Now, the single home historical district, that's the terminology that needs to take place.

[Robert Penta]: That's what puts the preservation restriction on this piece of property.

[Robert Penta]: And Tufts University, if they want to really be the good neighbor, they can come up to the plate.

[Robert Penta]: They have two good bites of the apple of this.

[Robert Penta]: They can lead on this one here if they want.

[Robert Penta]: They can make the application to the Commonwealth of Mass, for which there is a pamphlet that tells you that it's called There is a Difference.

[Robert Penta]: It's all from the Mass Historical Society.

[Robert Penta]: establishing historical districts, there's a dish they have out on them.

[Robert Penta]: What they could do, they could go forward and make this application in behalf of preserving the piece of property.

[Robert Penta]: Or in the alternative, what they could do, they could place a restriction on their deed.

[Robert Penta]: So any subsequent for value who purchases that, which would be the next person for value, there would be a deed restriction that would be recorded at the Middlesex South Registry of Deeds in perpetuity, which means

[Robert Penta]: it could never be subdivided.

[Robert Penta]: The house and the land stays as one.

[Robert Penta]: And that's all that the neighbors are looking for, to preserve their neighborhood.

[Robert Penta]: Because if that does get itself subdivided and other houses go there, you will have an increase in parking, you will have an increase of traffic in the neighborhood for which they don't need at the present time.

[Robert Penta]: As members of the Medford City Council, I believe you do.

[Robert Penta]: If you really believe in history and preserving it and keeping it as a part of what the city of Medford's all about,

[Robert Penta]: You do have a responsibility, and I would probably suggest and ask that you fellows and ladies make a pitch to the Medford Historical Commission to support the residents and the abutters and the people of Medford who want to keep this house as an historical piece of property and for the city of Medford to file with the Commonwealth of Mass Historical Commission.

[Robert Penta]: If in fact Tufts University won't do it, in either way,

[Robert Penta]: to preserve this as a historical landmark here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: You know, Tufts University, this isn't like new to them.

[Robert Penta]: They just got through doing this on grandfather's house on South Street.

[Robert Penta]: And fortunately, on this piece of property, the residents are aware, they're smart enough, and they now realize what's going on.

[Robert Penta]: That didn't happen on South Street, unfortunately.

[Robert Penta]: That happened in the summertime.

[Robert Penta]: This one here is a little bit more advanced where the neighborhood was aware of it.

[Robert Penta]: the meetings of October 29th, 2015, what was presented that time to Tufts University that they would go forward and sell the property with the request of maintaining a historical piece of property, but not to disallow them to subdivide it.

[Robert Penta]: And at that point in time, the developer and Tufts was not going to agree with that.

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't cost a lot of money to make this filing of this application.

[Robert Penta]: And what you're doing is you're preserving

[Robert Penta]: something that the city has had.

[Robert Penta]: If anybody knows the history of that property, it goes way back, way before 1840.

[Robert Penta]: It goes back to two brothers that owned that piece of property, who were involved not only in shipbuilding, but were also involved in marketing, you know, internationally.

[Robert Penta]: And as the lady who just came and spoke before us, there are other houses on South Street that don't have an historical designation, and if they lose it, and somebody comes in and buys it, nobody's going to be able to do anything about it, because that's going to be their right to do it, whoever buys it to subdivide it.

[Robert Penta]: The purchase of a value will give Tufts University the money.

[Robert Penta]: They'll make their money.

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't make any difference.

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't make any difference.

[Robert Penta]: and enjoy the land that's around it.

[Robert Penta]: It was over here, I'm sorry.

[Robert Penta]: We went through every single word, every single sentence, the spelling, and the proper pronunciation.

[Robert Penta]: in grammatical corrections, excuse me.

[Robert Penta]: So I would strongly suggest that the more multiple meetings that you have, the better it's going to be.

[Robert Penta]: And even if somebody wants to repeat themselves.

[Robert Penta]: And the input that people brought could sometimes change your mind.

[Robert Penta]: You become so stereotyped through the years because you never had this opportunity to hear somebody else speak or what their ideas might be.

[Robert Penta]: We had six public hearings.

[Robert Penta]: And you couldn't ask for more than that.

[Robert Penta]: The final vote was six to three.

[Robert Penta]: Doesn't make any difference.

[Robert Penta]: The law allows you to have that.

[Robert Penta]: You have two assistant superintendents, well in excess of $120,000.

[Robert Penta]: They have a responsibility to this community, whether it's your kids, my kids, grandchildren, or someone else's children.

[Robert Penta]: And that's to ensure that when they go to that school, barring any unforeseen circumstance, and if something were to happen, the parent should be advised ASAP.

[Robert Penta]: I wouldn't want a superintendent or a teacher to say whether they make the decision whether my child should be there or not.

[Robert Penta]: It's kind of like interesting.

[Robert Penta]: If you follow the whole idea about testing and MCAS and everything else and Common Core and draw the correlation to it, if the child or the parent doesn't want the kid to take it, they can opt out.

[Robert Penta]: magnify that to a bomb threat in a building and not tell the parent for eight hours after the fact.

[Robert Penta]: There is no correlation.

[Robert Penta]: There is no justice to this whole thing.

[Robert Penta]: And whatever comes out of this meeting tomorrow night, I hope it just proves one thing that those who were responsible, who didn't do their job are charged for not doing their job.

[Robert Penta]: They're replaced.

[Robert Penta]: And we have a system in place that you don't have to have this type of a conversation.

[Robert Penta]: I applaud you, Councilor Longo, for bringing this forward because this gets to the very heart of the citizens of Medford, its children, its core, its future for tomorrow.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Welcome.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penter.

[Robert Penta]: I live at Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: Last week we had a conversation regarding these, this position and the issue as it relates to, um, since we're talking about the chief of staff position right now, um, the concern that a chief of staff would have, especially as it relates to the working operation, not only of the mayor's office, but the interaction of all department heads and employees here in the city of Medford and outside concerns.

[Robert Penta]: or the president administration just refuses to, um, abide by it.

[Robert Penta]: If you've already had a chief of staff since January 5th of this year, that is a known fact that should not be allowed to take place, temporary or otherwise.

[Robert Penta]: There is nothing in state law.

[Robert Penta]: There is no state statute.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penter.

[Robert Penta]: I live at Zero Summit Road in Massachusetts, and I think we're in an area right now where we have a unique opportunity to really look at what our audiences are saying and where we can be going, because if we're going to relegate ourselves to changing audiences, maybe we should just look at the total picture.

[Robert Penta]: The total picture revolves itself around to the victor goes to spoils, and I understand that.

[Robert Penta]: But rather than change our municipal ordinance or any ordinance, maybe we ought to take advantage of what the law already allows for.

[Robert Penta]: The new administration does have a unique opportunity to hire any individual he or she would like.

[Robert Penta]: Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 4, Section 7, Sixth A, allows for coterminous appointments that would exist to that of the mayor in this particular situation.

[Robert Penta]: And what would happen there, that the individual who would be appointed would not be subject to any municipal ordinance.

[Robert Penta]: They would just be subject to this particular law, which happens to be state statute, and every person that's in the mayor's office, which is an administrative appointment, would find itself in a co-terminus position as it relates to the term that the mayor sits in that office.

[Robert Penta]: If, in fact, a new mayor were to come in in the future, the person sitting in that position would then be reviewed

[Robert Penta]: at a subsequent time by the then new mayor for the purposes of whether they continue to be coterminous or whether in fact they are going to be eliminated.

[Robert Penta]: They would come under the same privileges of having a review to their job, their job application, and what have you.

[Robert Penta]: The second portion that you would have to look at is these individuals are serving at an at-will position.

[Robert Penta]: The mayor chooses individuals to work in that particular office, his or her office.

[Robert Penta]: And by looking at having that person sit in that particular office, you have to take into consideration the fact that are we putting people in there because of a municipal ordinance?

[Robert Penta]: Are we putting people in there because it's going to be coterminous?

[Robert Penta]: Are we putting those people in there because they're at will?

[Robert Penta]: Now, if you look at all the state rules and laws and regulations as it relates to at-will contracts, you can have these made in such a way that you can fire them and hire them anytime they want.

[Robert Penta]: They can leave anytime they want.

[Robert Penta]: You can have an employment contract that basically relegates what their terms and duties are in this particular office.

[Robert Penta]: And to do that, that sets the tempo of making sure that you do have and you have hired the right person.

[Robert Penta]: For example, you might hire somebody and the person just doesn't work out six, seven months down the road.

[Robert Penta]: Then what are you going to do?

[Robert Penta]: If you stick with the municipal ordinance the way it is, you're not going to have the same luxury of either an at-will or a coterminous type of an individual, because that way the other review factor would be part and parcel of what's going on.

[Robert Penta]: Second of all, and more importantly, whether it's this position or any other position, you have to look at the conflict of interest issue that revolves around the people in this particular case.

[Robert Penta]: In this particular case, you already have one individual that's working in the office, I believe it was on or about January,

[Robert Penta]: in January, early January, and this individual also happens to be on the, on the transition team.

[Robert Penta]: Well, being on a transition team and also getting paid by the city of Medford for being an individual working in the mayor's office right now, I think presents itself, Mr. Solicitor.

[Robert Penta]: And I asked the question, I begged the question, so to speak, is there a conflict of interest?

[Robert Penta]: Because the impartiality of a transition team is supposed to bring the recommendations

[Robert Penta]: to the administration.

[Robert Penta]: But when you're getting paid by the administration, and you're also on this transition team, you're also, I think, if you look under the conflict of interest law, you're possibly looking or possibly indicating that there could be a conflict, there might be a conflict, or it could appear to be a conflict.

[Robert Penta]: And really, that's what you don't want right now, especially starting off with a brand new administration.

[Robert Penta]: So I would suggest to my colleagues, as you review this thing in your committee of the whole, that you

[Robert Penta]: look into this thing a little bit further, over and beyond changing a municipal ordinance or adding or subtracting to it, and look at the term that's allowed by state statute under the term of being either coterminous or at-will employees, because your responsibility back to the taxpayers is not the same as that of the administration.

[Robert Penta]: If you appropriate money for those particular positions, the question then becomes, after that appropriation, you have absolutely no control.

[Robert Penta]: You'll have absolutely no control over that employee.

[Robert Penta]: other than the chief executive officer making the final decision.

[Robert Penta]: So if you want to ask the hard questions, this is the time to do it.

[Robert Penta]: But you do have options, and your options are either serve coterminously, number one, at will, number two, and more importantly, I think you really need to look at the conflict of interest that presently exists in the office, because I don't think it's right that someone who's on the transition team at the same time is getting paid well in excess of $90,000 to sit in the mayor's office at the present time and take on another job and duty and responsibility.

[Robert Penta]: the same job and duty of responsibility that will come up in the next issue that's going to be presented before you.

[Robert Penta]: I could tell you many stories about Paul Camuso.

[Robert Penta]: I first met Paul when he drove up to my house many, many years ago before he decided to run for school committee.

[Robert Penta]: And from that point on,

[Robert Penta]: It became a relationship.

[Robert Penta]: Because if it wasn't for him, a lot of these issues really would never be magnified to the point that they are.

[Robert Penta]: Whether you were a supporter or a proponent for the mayor or not or vice versa.

[Robert Penta]: He made it very interesting because sometimes that's what you really need.

[Robert Penta]: You need this discourse.

[Robert Penta]: You need this difference of opinion.

[Robert Penta]: And when you have a difference of opinion, that's when you learn sometimes what the issue is about.

[Robert Penta]: And when the issue is being presented sometimes, you just lose concept of it.

[Robert Penta]: But Paul and I, I believe we've had many, many differences.

[Robert Penta]: But as he has said, at the end of the night, he'll come over and shake your hand, or I'll go over and talk to him, shake his hand.
