[Robert Penta]: This city did not follow any of the guidelines, none of the renewal quotes, and as it relates to that, and as a result, that's why we don't have public access.

[Robert Penta]: It's not Comcast.

[Robert Penta]: He doesn't own it.

[Robert Penta]: And that's what's wrong.

[Robert Penta]: The reason why we wanted to get rid of Channel 3 was because it's despicable actions.

[Robert Penta]: It's a lack of accounting for money.

[Robert Penta]: It's a lack of keeping minutes of records.

[Robert Penta]: It's a lack of allowing people to come and speak, and it's a lack of doing the community work.

[Robert Penta]: And for the people who were running it at the time, their complete abuse and misuse of their 501c3 prerogative, that's what is wrong.

[Robert Penta]: Including or concurring with the remarks of Councilor Knight, I think what we need is a report back from our city solicitor that basically addresses the fact that it's a concern here within our community.

[Robert Penta]: And since it's an allowable or

[Robert Penta]: appearing to be an allowable use according to our zoning, I think what needs to be addressed is maybe addressing the licensure division back in Boston and indicating to them that something like this should come under the authority of the local legislative body rather than a state agency because the effect of the granting of this particular license does affect the community, whether it's abutting a residential, commercial, or what have you.

[Robert Penta]: And with that being said, I would ask that

[Robert Penta]: if this is what the case needs to be, that our city solicitor provide to us the legalese in writing to support either a recommendation, I don't know, I think it would be a home rule petition, it might be just a waiver of rules and regulations that the Division of Licensure might have at the present time to support local communities, whether they want it or they won't want it, because unfortunately there is no public hearing, there is no public commentary on this,

[Robert Penta]: Councilor Knight just alluded to, they could go anywhere they want because the Commonwealth of Massachusetts is allowing this to their license or division.

[Robert Penta]: So I'm going to move that as an amendment to the resolution to find out just where we can go with this.

[Robert Penta]: I'm glad Councilman Marks brought this up because the interesting component about this is when we had a conversation about this a few months back, I introduced the offering as what they did and I don't have my notes with me right now, so I apologize.

[Robert Penta]: But in Florida, they had a particular community where their downtown areas were exactly as Councilman Marks was alluding to.

[Robert Penta]: And what they did is they made offerings to the owners of the property either with tax incentives or employment incentives or community-based incentives.

[Robert Penta]: which would have allowed the owner of the property, whoever he rented out to, to get one of these benefits for the purposes of coming in.

[Robert Penta]: And what they did is they sort of like took a particular street, and what they just did, from A to B to C to D. Now about three weeks ago, I went and I heard the lady who works for the community of Lowell, and she is not the community office director, but she is the director, I believe,

[Robert Penta]: cultural resources.

[Robert Penta]: And what they did is they took street by street.

[Robert Penta]: And what they did, as Councilor Marks alluded to, they've alluded, they went from one street to the next street and just jumped.

[Robert Penta]: And they just piggybacked all the way around to an entire portion of the town.

[Robert Penta]: Where now, it doesn't happen overnight, but you need to have a beginning.

[Robert Penta]: And that's what the beginning is.

[Robert Penta]: It's unfortunate that this administration does not realize that, didn't take advantage of it.

[Robert Penta]: We've talked about revitalizing Medford Square three times in the

[Robert Penta]: past 20 years, and it hasn't happened.

[Robert Penta]: But what needs to happen is the business people.

[Robert Penta]: And this is a true test now for the Chamber of Commerce to come to life and say, hey, you know, we want good businesses to be here in Medford Square.

[Robert Penta]: We want to be a working partner here with the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: And if this is the issue tonight, and it really brings it to head, then so be it.

[Robert Penta]: And I think you're right, Councilor Marks.

[Robert Penta]: I just think this is the time.

[Robert Penta]: The people really need to know, you know, what their government is doing.

[Robert Penta]: You know, what is the forecast?

[Robert Penta]: What is the plan?

[Robert Penta]: you know, what's the open window and the fresh air going to be all about as it relates to where we're going.

[Robert Penta]: So I support, I support your thoughts and I can assure you that that would be in my plan.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Can we take 15552?

[Robert Penta]: Because I told some business people we would be addressing that.

[Robert Penta]: within the first hour.

[Robert Penta]: If anybody were to go to Medford Square and just look at the 5 High Street building that's there now, they've had scaffolding and staging there for well over in excess of three months.

[Robert Penta]: It's an absolute disgrace.

[Robert Penta]: It's an eyesore.

[Robert Penta]: It's a public health and it's a public safety issue.

[Robert Penta]: This is what I don't understand.

[Robert Penta]: How long does it take for something like that to stay there before it causes a real harm and a real problem to the people within this community?

[Robert Penta]: The owner of the property should be held accountable.

[Robert Penta]: It's been like that for three months.

[Robert Penta]: There's no work.

[Robert Penta]: There has been no work that's been done other than putting up the scaffolding.

[Robert Penta]: And nobody knows what the reason is.

[Robert Penta]: It surrounds the entire building.

[Robert Penta]: If surrounding the entire building and the parapet has a problem, well, there's no work that's been done on it.

[Robert Penta]: I just think it's unfair to every other business person that does what they're supposed to do in the square.

[Robert Penta]: We just had a conversation out tonight of putting a massage parlor on Riverside Avenue.

[Robert Penta]: And that's as bad as looking at a parapet because, again, it serves no particular purpose.

[Robert Penta]: It offers no intrinsic value to the community of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: It absolutely is an eyesight.

[Robert Penta]: And, as I said, it's a public safety, health, and a building department issue.

[Robert Penta]: I've seen people walk underneath that.

[Robert Penta]: I saw it today yesterday, when I was walking, a lady with a baby carriage.

[Robert Penta]: And she had to move her baby carriage out from under because, unfortunately, the other lady who was walking down was in a walker.

[Robert Penta]: And, you know, so that was nice of her to do that, but there should have been no reason for her to do that because she had to go out underneath it and then bring herself back in.

[Robert Penta]: So I'm asking, Mr. President, that our building department find out who that owner is immediately.

[Robert Penta]: and find out what the reason is.

[Robert Penta]: And if no work is being done there, then take that scaffolding down because it's serving absolutely no purpose at all.

[Robert Penta]: And it's just absolutely making Medford Square look exactly what people are saying it is.

[Robert Penta]: It's a no man's land town.

[Robert Penta]: It offers nothing.

[Robert Penta]: It shows you nothing.

[Robert Penta]: And I don't want that to be an example of what we're offering in Medford Square.

[Robert Penta]: I think it was $30,000, $40,000, and that's to integrate the entire system so people could jump onto it for the purposes of reviewing it.

[Robert Penta]: These are the working instruments that these department heads need.

[Robert Penta]: And when you turn around and try to explain to the taxpayer, you have $6.5 million in surplus, and we have $7.5 million, $7.5 million in our water and sewer enterprise account because we're trying to stay financially stable.

[Robert Penta]: Well, I'm going to lead into the

[Robert Penta]: report, the 2014 report ending by our outside consultant that says the following.

[Robert Penta]: The city does not have a formal investment policy that limits investment maturities as a means of managing its exposure to fair value losses arising from increasing interest rates.

[Robert Penta]: Now, we hear all around here that this city is so well maintained in its bond rating and what it goes out to do.

[Robert Penta]: Now, here's an outside auditing company and says we have no

[Robert Penta]: formal investment policy to protect us in that particular area.

[Robert Penta]: And that's a multimillion-dollar building, not a $2 million building.

[Robert Penta]: And we were really running the string on that one there.

[Robert Penta]: Okay.

[Robert Penta]: Now we just reviewed tonight's health budget and it's an increase of almost $700,000, but now group health insurance, we're transferring $102,000 from apparently last year's, uh,

[Robert Penta]: What I don't understand, if this is all coming under GIC, this is a huge shift in payments here.

[Robert Penta]: You're saving $102,000 in one year, and you're going to increase of $700,000.

[Robert Penta]: Anyone who's on GIC needs to understand that the Patrick administration left office $192 million with Group Insurance Commission in debt because they didn't fund it for the last three years.

[Robert Penta]: So cities and towns now had to pick that up.

[Robert Penta]: when there were 50 cities and towns.

[Robert Penta]: Now there are 60 cities and towns.

[Robert Penta]: That's 10 more cities and towns than when they first started out with, or before Medford even jumped on board.

[Robert Penta]: That's more members, that's more payments, and now the fees are going up.

[Robert Penta]: I believe the legislature bailed out the $192,000.

[Robert Penta]: And I just don't understand why cities and towns such as ourselves are gonna have to pay for this increase that we were told before by going to GIC, members that are in GIC,

[Robert Penta]: over time would have a reduction in rate, and the city of Medford would save over the next five and a half, six years approximately $24 million in insurance claims.

[Robert Penta]: I just think this is very confusing to the individual rate payer who might be an employee.

[Robert Penta]: But I just think it's really unfair that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts would be doing this, because all it looks like it's another way of beating around a state budget, especially that deals with cities and towns.

[Robert Penta]: And when you're asking cities and towns to be involved, it's like asking the taxpayers in the city.

[Robert Penta]: You have a seven and a half million dollar surplus in your water and sewer account, but we're going to raise your rates.

[Robert Penta]: This is a complete reverse.

[Robert Penta]: Here you are with 50 cities and towns hoping to get lower rates and they don't fund it and they don't fund it for the last three years.

[Robert Penta]: I just think that's a public comment that I'd like to make.

[Robert Penta]: You're taking $80,000 out of highway salaries.

[Robert Penta]: This is really a tough one to deal with.

[Robert Penta]: But when that child picks up a book and opens it and reads it and understands what's in that book and puts a smile on his face, whether it's for pleasure or entertainment or whether it's for education, that is great.

[Robert Penta]: That's the fastest way to lose a patron to come to your Medford Public Library.

[Robert Penta]: I don't believe in that.

[Robert Penta]: I won't accept it.

[Robert Penta]: A public library is like a school.

[Robert Penta]: It's a basis of education.

[Robert Penta]: It's a central point in this community of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: You folks out there tonight, and those who might be watching, you folks made this happen.

[Robert Penta]: You were the actionary force that called the mayor's hand.

[Robert Penta]: And that's how you got it done.

[Robert Penta]: And I hope this doesn't have to be done in every other part of this budget.

[Robert Penta]: But you folks should be complimenting yourselves, knowing your kids are going to have a library.

[Robert Penta]: And if I have my way, you won't ever have to come before this podium to ask for this again, because it'll be there each and every year like it's supposed to be.

[Robert Penta]: And the more you tell people that this is going to be almost four years, they can't believe it.

[Robert Penta]: A 121-foot bridge is going to take almost four years to get itself built.

[Robert Penta]: with the state of technology that's out there today, with the state of construction that's out there today.

[Robert Penta]: It's mind-boggling.

[Robert Penta]: And then the second aspect of this is the MBTA.

[Robert Penta]: They've never come back.

[Robert Penta]: We've asked to have them come back over here.

[Robert Penta]: The possibility of looking at putting the bus stop on Riverside Avenue, go down Riverside Avenue, change the route of River Street, have the bus go there, park there, comes back around the square,

[Robert Penta]: and then it goes through without tying up anybody.

[Robert Penta]: Maybe no more than three to four extra minutes out of the normal route that it takes.

[Robert Penta]: Think about it, you're talking about the seniors that live at 99 and the folks that live at 121.

[Robert Penta]: The way they have it projected now, you're gonna have to walk all the way down the ring road and then from under the ring road, you're gonna have to walk underneath the bridge over by 101 Main Street to get the bus.

[Robert Penta]: Where now, if you follow the riverside to the river street, all they'd be doing is walking into Medford Square and picking up the bus there.

[Robert Penta]: And all you'd be doing is displacing four car spaces that you could put, where you would be putting the buses.

[Robert Penta]: These are all options and these are all possibilities that need to be discussed.

[Robert Penta]: And the Medford City Council is the controller of the parking of the bus stops here in the city of Medford, not the MBTA.

[Robert Penta]: It's the city of Medford, the Medford City Council.

[Robert Penta]: So, Mr. President, what I'm proposing, in concert with Councilor Camuso's resolution, that we look at, is the MBTA coming to this meeting too?

[Robert Penta]: But is the person from the MBTA going to be here?

[Robert Penta]: But the last time we had this, Adam,

[Robert Penta]: The lady from the MBTA had to be, she was invited separately.

[Robert Penta]: Cause we were saying we never had this meeting.

[Robert Penta]: I think maybe about a year and a half ago.

[Robert Penta]: So I would like to make sure in your invite on the 30th, um, that a representative or the person from the MBTA who would be involved here in the city of method regarding bus stops is here and to, um, so we could explore once again, changing the bus stop instead of 21 main street to river street.

[Robert Penta]: Redirecting the traffic and all those that just come around.

[Robert Penta]: But I think what we need to discuss is not a matter of having a discussion,

[Robert Penta]: I think a matter of having them know.

[Robert Penta]: No, a matter of a discussion expressing what our ideas would be and not to have them come back six, nine months later and decide to make a decision.

[Robert Penta]: This project is already designed, drawn up, has a battle plan and they're implementing it.

[Robert Penta]: And without any support or input from this council or the taxpayers of this community.

[Robert Penta]: So all these meetings that supposedly were going to take place and be so transparent,

[Robert Penta]: just never took place.

[Robert Penta]: So they're just going ahead and building what they want to build.

[Robert Penta]: 10,000, excuse me, now it's up to 10 million, 10.1.

[Robert Penta]: So we've gone from 2.5 to 8.5 to 12.7, now down to 10.7.

[Robert Penta]: So we really don't even know what the true cost of this project is, because we've already had one, two, three, we've had five separate numbers.

[Robert Penta]: So, you know, it's a bridge.

[Robert Penta]: It's not a mausoleum.

[Robert Penta]: It's not an historical edifice.

[Robert Penta]: It's just a plain, simple bridge to make buses, cars, and traffic and trucks drive over.

[Robert Penta]: This is not the Longfellow Bridge in Boston, where you're looking at architectural scheme and design.

[Robert Penta]: It's 121 feet, Fred.

[Robert Penta]: That may be in your opinion.

[Robert Penta]: On the motion.

[Robert Penta]: With the invitation.

[Robert Penta]: On the motion of Councilor Penter, all those in favor?

[Robert Penta]: Maybe I misunderstood it.

[Robert Penta]: You have what you call a retention

[Robert Penta]: in your example.

[Robert Penta]: Yes.

[Robert Penta]: And if that's the case, how many cars would you proposing for how many units?

[Robert Penta]: Yes.

[Robert Penta]: beneficial with a community.

[Robert Penta]: First of all, our charter as it presently sits is, you're right, it's approximately 30 years old.

[Robert Penta]: And probably the biggest shortcoming in that charter is the fact that there was no review process to take place.

[Robert Penta]: As in everything else in government, a review is necessary.

[Robert Penta]: We as candidates are reviewed every two years when we're being voted on for office.

[Robert Penta]: I look at our city's charter

[Robert Penta]: is to be the future.

[Robert Penta]: It's the future of this city as we're going forward.

[Robert Penta]: As Mr. DiBenedetto indicated, you know, it's the city has changed.

[Robert Penta]: It's changed dramatically.

[Robert Penta]: Dating back to the plan E and the plan A form of government, the mayor did serve both as the chairperson then as he serves now on the school committee.

[Robert Penta]: But that may be something that may want to be reviewed at and looked at right now by folks within this community.

[Robert Penta]: As a candidate for mayor, one of the first things I will propose is to have the city auditor come under the control of the city council.

[Robert Penta]: That will present the checks and balances as to how the city administration spends its money and how it can't spend its money.

[Robert Penta]: We don't have that.

[Robert Penta]: Unfortunately, every single department comes under the control of the mayor as it presently stands in this particular charter.

[Robert Penta]: What councillors, whether you're for it or against it, some people like at large,

[Robert Penta]: Some people like ward Councilors.

[Robert Penta]: Again, it's an option.

[Robert Penta]: I think after 30 years, people deserve to have that ability to look at it.

[Robert Penta]: Term limits.

[Robert Penta]: Do we need term limits?

[Robert Penta]: Is it fair to say, especially for the office of mayor, the term limits should only be two years.

[Robert Penta]: Maybe it should be a four, no more than two four-year terms.

[Robert Penta]: And maybe we should have staggered or proposed staggered city council terms, one, two, and three years, both city council and school committee.

[Robert Penta]: That gives everybody an opportunity each and every year

[Robert Penta]: whether they want to serve or whether they don't want to serve, but it keeps the people involved in the community as to what's going on.

[Robert Penta]: Also, the fact that the mayor, under this form of government, does have an extended amount of power.

[Robert Penta]: But remember what the plan A charter says.

[Robert Penta]: The plan A charter says that the mayor is not required to meet with the council.

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't say he can't.

[Robert Penta]: He's not required to.

[Robert Penta]: And that would make a huge difference as to what I would be proposing.

[Robert Penta]: I would meet with this council.

[Robert Penta]: when and if asked, and that should be something that should be incorporated in the new proposal for the charter.

[Robert Penta]: Now, the gentleman that talked about the affordable housing in the city of Medford, if anybody understands how you get to the affordable housing content, if a developer were to come into this community and propose 100 units, and only 25% of those units are for affordable housing, the city gets credit for all 100.

[Robert Penta]: That's the way this archaic 1939 law has been written.

[Robert Penta]: That needs to be changed in the legislature.

[Robert Penta]: This city, I will say, has gone out of its way through its limited resources in the Office of Community Development to bring in as much affordable housing as they can.

[Robert Penta]: And even by adding on those other numbers at the very end, we still haven't been able to reach that 10% mark on new development for affordable housing.

[Robert Penta]: The other parts I think that need to be looked upon is that not only the diversity that this community has, but where is the opportunity for the citizens of this community to know

[Robert Penta]: that their government not only can be looked upon, it can be reviewed, but they don't have to wait for a four or a five-year period.

[Robert Penta]: I believe if I understand the law correctly and reviewing on the charters, you can have a five-year charter review, and if it incorporates a particular aspect of it, you don't have to go through that next five-year process to make that change.

[Robert Penta]: And I think in part that's what you're asking for with this resolution with the city solicitor to talk about.

[Robert Penta]: And I think these are the things that need to be incorporated in the speaking of it.

[Robert Penta]: But the checks and balances just does not exist in this city.

[Robert Penta]: Now, campaigning for this office, am I talking against myself by having the auditor not be on my side and on the council side?

[Robert Penta]: No.

[Robert Penta]: That's just what good government's all about, having a good audit of your system on how your government works.

[Robert Penta]: That's the key to let you know that your government, your tax dollars are being spent wisely and correctly.

[Robert Penta]: This is a hard job sometimes.

[Robert Penta]: We just got our budget here tonight.

[Robert Penta]: And unfortunately, in this budget,

[Robert Penta]: that we got, it's a combination of the prior budget director and the at present budget director.

[Robert Penta]: And in some occasions, one not talking to the other, as it relates to a particular thing that this council has asked for in each and every budget, the wishlist of each and every department head.

[Robert Penta]: Give us the wishlist, why you need it, how much it's going to cost, and how do you think you'd be able to get to that to pay for it?

[Robert Penta]: And we don't get that.

[Robert Penta]: We just get rank and file, whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: During the past two years, we've seen increases in this city take place.

[Robert Penta]: Last year alone and last year's budget, the school department increased by $2 million.

[Robert Penta]: Absolutely no conversation with the council about it.

[Robert Penta]: There was no concern as it related to rank and file teachers, books and students, but it was a lot went to administration.

[Robert Penta]: But just think about the school system we have here.

[Robert Penta]: It went for almost 50 plus years with having no rehabilitation.

[Robert Penta]: And during that course of the 50 years, the school system just deteriorated.

[Robert Penta]: So what did they do 12, 13 years ago?

[Robert Penta]: They decided to build new buildings.

[Robert Penta]: And yes, at that time, I was against the new buildings, because I felt we could rehab our old buildings one at a time.

[Robert Penta]: But the city decided to go the other way, so be it.

[Robert Penta]: Now, as we Councilor Calderiello disclosed in his first term, these 12-year-old buildings are over in excess of $1 million in repairs that are needed.

[Robert Penta]: They've never taken the option

[Robert Penta]: that the law has told them that 5% of the annual budget for each school needs to be put there for reconditioning, upgrading or whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: We're hearing comments tonight in the meeting and we will be hearing it continuously in this budget of all the needs that need to take place.

[Robert Penta]: This city needs to take a step back and look at where it's at, where it wants to go and understand that we have a brand new future that's in front of us.

[Robert Penta]: The opportunity is so unique for this city to go forward.

[Robert Penta]: Forget the mayor's office, which is a very important issue, but we have two openings here in the city council and you have two openings on the school department, the school committee, excuse me.

[Robert Penta]: I would love to be a part of it.

[Robert Penta]: I'd love to have your vote, but I do support this charter vote.

[Robert Penta]: And I think this is very important.

[Robert Penta]: As I said, as I said, right in the beginning,

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, but more importantly, anybody who might be watching and Medford Square business folks,

[Robert Penta]: The situation regarding the Karatek Bridge is just an ongoing tale.

[Robert Penta]: So I think it's time to maybe have a little bit of a history lesson here as it relates to how did we get to the position we're in right now.

[Robert Penta]: We can go back to 2002, 02-2002-526, offered by Council Longo.

[Robert Penta]: Be it resolved that the Karatek Bridge be discussed in regards to public safety.

[Robert Penta]: And there was a whole host of amendments as it related to that.

[Robert Penta]: Now that was in 2002, 13 years ago.

[Robert Penta]: First response from the state came back in 2006.

[Robert Penta]: They first sent a note back that basically says that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts will be taking a look and to review it.

[Robert Penta]: Then we go to 2011.

[Robert Penta]: From 2006 to 2011, there was absolutely nothing that took place that revolved around that particular bridge.

[Robert Penta]: At that point in time in 2011, they said the cost of the bridge was going to be $2.5 million.

[Robert Penta]: Then in August of 2012,

[Robert Penta]: it jumped to $8.5 million.

[Robert Penta]: And then in April of 2013, it jumped up to $12.7 million.

[Robert Penta]: And at that meeting on April 13, on April, excuse me, of 2013, I had asked the question as it relates to mitigation for our downtown Medford business folks.

[Robert Penta]: The council voted seven to nothing on that.

[Robert Penta]: As a matter of fact, we got a letter of support from the Medford Chamber of Commerce on that particular issue.

[Robert Penta]: Sent the letter to the mayor and to the state, and to this date, still, absolutely nothing has come back.

[Robert Penta]: From April, we sent it again in May of 2013.

[Robert Penta]: June of 2013, the cost then went down to $10.7 million.

[Robert Penta]: And now, again, on February of 2014, the question of mitigation came up, it was presented, and we still have no answer to that.

[Robert Penta]: All we know right now that we're getting a bridge

[Robert Penta]: that supposedly are going to be starting at this point in time, sometime this summer.

[Robert Penta]: And what doesn't make sense now, they're saying that on November 4th of 2018, the bridge will be completed.

[Robert Penta]: But during the summer of 2018, the bridge will be open for use.

[Robert Penta]: So how can you have something not completed and open for use or be completed in November of 2018?

[Robert Penta]: And that cost now is projected at $10.78 million for this particular bridge.

[Robert Penta]: We've seen all kinds of correspondence from representatives in our city who are saying this is a wonderful thing, dating back to 2006, to 2012, to 2013.

[Robert Penta]: We've received press releases from the mayor, from the senator in this community, that this bridge is such a wonderful thing.

[Robert Penta]: You know, they built the tunnel from France to England, which was, I believe, 21 miles in less than nine years.

[Robert Penta]: And we have a bridge here starting in 2015 to be included by 2018, that's three years, to go 121 feet.

[Robert Penta]: Think about it, 121 feet when you built the tunnel, which was 21 miles, and it was underwater.

[Robert Penta]: This whole thing, as far as I'm concerned, is the biggest slap in the face

[Robert Penta]: to the Medford business community.

[Robert Penta]: And the sad part about it, one of the gentlemen who's in charge of this project lives in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: Now, Councilor Dello Russo, I'm calling you on the carpet tonight because you indicated that you'd never received the letter dated February 24th, for which your name is on here.

[Robert Penta]: Every single one of our reps, our senators, our state, Paul Geer, Cassandra upstairs in the engineer's office.

[Robert Penta]: And I accepted you for your comment saying that you couldn't find it in your file.

[Robert Penta]: But it was convenient for you last week to get Eversource here just like that, when the conditions of the streets might be taking place.

[Robert Penta]: But at the same time, this council has been asking, asking for you to go forward and call for this meeting.

[Robert Penta]: And there is no meeting here.

[Robert Penta]: But there are public notices out there, and there are stanchions out there indicating that the bridge is going to start this summer.

[Robert Penta]: So what clout you have, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: What clout this city has, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: But the more important part of where the clout all lies is this city council should be holding somebody to be accountable for the mitigation process that needs to take place on this, because businesses are going to be hurt, and some people might even go out of business.

[Robert Penta]: It's absolutely unfair that this project is going to start in the summer of 2015 and not be completed until November of 2018.

[Robert Penta]: With all due respect to my council colleague, that may be your interpretation, but nothing was ever definitively signed or put in writing.

[Robert Penta]: This council asked to have that put in the RFP that went out there.

[Robert Penta]: And there are four people, there are four components to the people who are bidding on that bridge, number one.

[Robert Penta]: This council asked that they come here and they apprise the city, the council, and the business community, and the Office of Community Development as it relates to the progress of that bridge.

[Robert Penta]: and they never did it.

[Robert Penta]: The only meeting that they ever had was, I believe, some three weeks ago at 10 o'clock on a Wednesday morning, for which certain councils couldn't go, a lot of people couldn't go, and it was just their staff meeting, if you want to come and see what it's all about.

[Robert Penta]: And then they send you a press release, for which is put in the paper, that basically tells you that this is not going to be completed until 2018.

[Robert Penta]: So if you forget all the gibberish that gets around to 2018, and then they acknowledge that the footings of the bridge, which have been there for 100 plus years, all they're going to do is reshore them up.

[Robert Penta]: That bridge is not sunk at all.

[Robert Penta]: And what they think they're building, the Taj Mahal, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: They don't need to build the Longfellow Bridge like they're building in Washington.

[Robert Penta]: This is a very simple bridge of 121 feet.

[Robert Penta]: Sure, you want to make it adaptable for people, sidewalks and bikes, go right ahead.

[Robert Penta]: But with the art of technology that's out there today, and for them to tell you it's going to take you a well over a year just to figure out what's underneath the bridge and move the lines and this and that, that is absolutely absurd.

[Robert Penta]: Absolutely absurd.

[Robert Penta]: It's probably the biggest snow job that this council and this city has gotten from the State Department of Public Transportation.

[Robert Penta]: And we haven't even gotten to the issue of the bus routes and the changing of the bus routes and what's going to happen after that and once this bridge goes into construction.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, I'm asking once again, I'm asking you to call the Mass.

[Robert Penta]: Department of Transportation, have them come before this council, and have them explain if what Councilor Camuso was saying is correct, that they are not going to give us mitigation.

[Robert Penta]: Point of information?

[Robert Penta]: Point of information, Councilor Camuso.

[Robert Penta]: Well, I'm going to respectfully disagree with my colleague because state agencies and state departments do pay mitigation.

[Robert Penta]: And if they're asked to do it, they do do it.

[Robert Penta]: The biggest one out there right now is the MWRA.

[Robert Penta]: They'll give you mitigation before they even start a project because they have to realize the length and the strength of their pipes.

[Robert Penta]: Well, I'm responsible for what I know.

[Robert Penta]: And what I know is this, that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts does and can, if the city of Medford is going to be impacted to such a degree and businesses are going to be displaced for a period of time such as that,

[Robert Penta]: It's a disgrace.

[Robert Penta]: It's been established.

[Robert Penta]: But whoever the administrator, and whoever the new council's gonna be, your job isn't for today, your job is how, where this city's gonna be going for tomorrow.

[Robert Penta]: It's direction, and how are we gonna enhance the vitality and rejuvenate this city to a point that's saying, hey, our government is working with us and it's moving forward with us.

[Robert Penta]: How it's gonna be financed, that's what you need to know.

[Robert Penta]: You just can't say you want something.

[Robert Penta]: You know, we're elected to do the people's business.

[Robert Penta]: We're not elected here to be for ourselves.

[Robert Penta]: There's no personal gain in here for me.

[Robert Penta]: I'll speak for myself.

[Robert Penta]: And there was a whole host of amendments as it related to that.

[Robert Penta]: Now that was in 2002, 13 years ago.

[Robert Penta]: The first response from the state came back in 2006.

[Robert Penta]: They first sent a note back that basically says that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts will be taking a look and to review it.

[Robert Penta]: Then we go to 2011.

[Robert Penta]: From 2006 to 2011, there was absolutely nothing that took place that revolved around that particular bridge.

[Robert Penta]: At that point in time in 2011, they said the cost of the bridge was going to be $2.5 million.

[Robert Penta]: Then in August of 2012,

[Robert Penta]: it jumped to $8.5 million.

[Robert Penta]: And then in April of 2013, it jumped up to $12.7 million.

[Robert Penta]: And at that meeting on April 13th, on April, excuse me, of 2013, I had asked the question as it relates to mitigation for our downtown Medford business folks.

[Robert Penta]: The council voted seven to nothing on that.

[Robert Penta]: As a matter of fact, we got a letter of support from the Medford Chamber of Commerce on that particular issue.

[Robert Penta]: Sent the letter to the mayor and to the state, and to this date, still, absolutely nothing has come back.

[Robert Penta]: From April, we sent it again in May of 2013.

[Robert Penta]: June of 2013, the cost then went down to $10.7 million.

[Robert Penta]: And now, again, on February of 2014, the question of mitigation came up.

[Robert Penta]: It was presented, and we still have no answer to that.

[Robert Penta]: All we know right now that we're getting a bridge

[Robert Penta]: that's supposedly going to be starting at this point in time, sometime this summer.

[Robert Penta]: And what doesn't make sense now, they're saying that on November 4th of 2018, the bridge will be completed.

[Robert Penta]: But during the summer of 2018, the bridge will be open for use.

[Robert Penta]: So how can you have something not completed and open for use or be completed in November of 2018?

[Robert Penta]: And that cost now is projected at $10.78 million for this particular bridge.

[Robert Penta]: We've seen all kinds of correspondence from representatives in our city who are saying this is a wonderful thing, dating back to 2006, to 2012, to 2013.

[Robert Penta]: We've received press releases from the mayor, from the senator in this community, that this bridge is such a wonderful thing.

[Robert Penta]: You know, they built the tunnel from France to England, which was, I believe, 21 miles in less than nine years.

[Robert Penta]: And we have a bridge here starting in 2015 to be included by 2018, that's three years, to go 121 feet.

[Robert Penta]: Think about it, 121 feet when you built the tunnel, which was 21 miles, and it was underwater.

[Robert Penta]: This whole thing, as far as I'm concerned, is the biggest slap in the face

[Robert Penta]: to the Medford business community.

[Robert Penta]: Because you know why?

[Robert Penta]: Because in all these bonds that the city has outstanding there, they're all going to be paid on a back end.

[Robert Penta]: So it's interest only for the first five or six years.

[Robert Penta]: God bless whoever the next mayor is going to be.

[Robert Penta]: this city is going to pay for those bonds in the future.

[Robert Penta]: This past year, the school department budget passed $2 million additional dollars, from last year to this year.

[Robert Penta]: God knows what they have in it for this year.

[Robert Penta]: Salaries increased, as the councilor to my right, Councilor Lungo-Koehn and current.

[Robert Penta]: Some people got $20,000 salary increases, and I believe there was almost $32 million in transfers from last year's budget before the end of the year took place.

[Robert Penta]: So how are we talking about that being a legitimate budget when you pass it in the beginning of the year?

[Robert Penta]: I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: These are all tricks of the trade, apparently, that have been going on for years.

[Robert Penta]: But if you have, all of a sudden, $2 million in additional dollars, and you start hiring extra people at $90,000 and $100,000 a year, and you take it away from the classroom, you take it away from the teachers, you take it away from the supplies, and you take it away from the front entrance of that high school, it looks like it's bombed out, like a war zone, because the bricks and everything are shattered.

[Robert Penta]: I'm surprised there are enough kids that have not broken their ankles or their legs.

[Robert Penta]: Handles are still off the front door to come in.

[Robert Penta]: That's wrong.

[Robert Penta]: And when a parent goes up there and looks at it and says, is that where I'm going to send my kid?

[Robert Penta]: Do I really want my kid to go there?

[Robert Penta]: That's why they get forced to go to these private schools, because appearance, as you know, is the name of the game.

[Robert Penta]: They spent $500,000 to redo this building over, just this council chamber.

[Robert Penta]: I think it cost $497,000 to build the entire building, PWA days.

[Robert Penta]: But $500,000 to do this over.

[Robert Penta]: That's been like that for three years.

[Robert Penta]: And then the molding, if you look at the molding, that's ready to go and that's coming down and nothing's been done, nothing in the budget, no repair work, no nothing.

[Robert Penta]: And y'all worried about a police station and they can't even figure out how to do this.

[Robert Penta]: The next administration hopefully will be a work in composite between the council and the mayor.

[Robert Penta]: And there's going to be a meeting of the minds.

[Robert Penta]: And so that way there, when the money is going to be spent, it's going to be spent, and everybody's going to be on board to understand how it's going to be spent, when it's going to be spent, and where it's going to be spent for.

[Robert Penta]: That hasn't taken place here in 28 years.

[Robert Penta]: But I can assure you, it will take place.

[Robert Penta]: we laid on the table last week to this week.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, as a result of unfortunately the merger that did not take place between partners and Lawrence Memorial hospital and the Melrose Wakefield on January 29th of this past year,

[Robert Penta]: when Judge Sanders issued her 48-page decision not agreeing to this because she did not believe that what Martha Coakley had put together was going to work in the best interests of the hospitals mentioned in as well as offshore.

[Robert Penta]: And then on top of that, Mara Healy, the new attorney general coming in and likewise not only supporting the judge but nixing the whole deal and is willing to go to court

[Robert Penta]: I believe we have a council resolution asking her and both parties to be here.

[Robert Penta]: I've taken the time to speak to some doctors and some employees up at the Lawrence Memorial Hospital.

[Robert Penta]: And since at the present time, the third and the fourth floor of the hospital is not being used to any type of its potential, nevermind its maximum, I'd like to make an offering and throw this back out.

[Robert Penta]: And hopefully it gets back to not only the Lawrence Memorial, but to partners because

[Robert Penta]: If we take a look at the doctors that are operating here in the city of Medford that are Hallmark Hospital doctors and at the same time private practitioners, and offer them room and space on the third and fourth floor of the hospital, and leaving the first and second floors available for emergency, for prompt care, emergency services, and what's presently in there right now, it would be a way not only to utilize the hospital

[Robert Penta]: with a complete medical density of doctors, no matter what their professions might be, and at the same time, make the offering to partners, rather than have the Lawrence be part of a consortium, which included the South Shore, which included Melrose-Wakefield.

[Robert Penta]: It could be an independent, isolated medical facility that the partners, Mass General, would be willing to entertain, which would not have to go through any type of a consortium, or review, or to go through

[Robert Penta]: 48-page review.

[Robert Penta]: People don't realize that the Lawrence Memorial Hospital was in a profit-making position before this whole idea of this merger took place.

[Robert Penta]: And for the last few years, a lot of its finances and a lot of its profits have been carried over to the Melrose-Wakefield.

[Robert Penta]: And unfortunately for the Lawrence Memorial, they did not receive the same benefits that the Melrose-Wakefield Hospital has received most recently over the past two to three years.

[Robert Penta]: And that's maybe because the former president, who's no longer the president, who left the day after the deal didn't go through, did not have the same feeling to the Lawrence Memorial as he had as being president over at the Melrose-Wakefield.

[Robert Penta]: But I think this would really bode well for our community.

[Robert Penta]: I think it would bode well for our citizens, seniors, mothers with babies, emergency room, prompt care locations, and for any other doctor that might be having a situation where

[Robert Penta]: either parking presents itself with a problem, location presents itself with a problem, but if they were all centrally located, because everybody knows where the Lawrence Memorial Hospital is, and if they were centrally located there, and they worked their offices out of that building, and even if they looked at the positioning that the doctors, to some degree, are not part of the nonprofit, and there is a way to legally separate the buildings or the floors or what have you, because anything is possible.

[Robert Penta]: So that's why I'm throwing this out there as a possibility

[Robert Penta]: to keep as many doctors as we can here, but also the greater possibility to bring Mass General partners here into the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: They have a great interest in Mr. Cardiology.

[Robert Penta]: They think it's a great team of doctors that are there.

[Robert Penta]: They were one of the first, if not the first group of doctors that partners, I believe, entertain for the purposes of hopefully being part of this consortium.

[Robert Penta]: had put in her request for the merger that the cost would not be contained, as they said it would be for a six-year period of time.

[Robert Penta]: That's what the 48-page decision says.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, before I speak, we have in attendance this evening the president of the state organization from Mass Resistance, Mr. Brian Kamenker.

[Robert Penta]: And I'd like to have him come forward and give his reasoning first before I make my comments.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, I want to thank the president for being here.

[Robert Penta]: I think the bill, the intent of the bill needs to be said.

[Robert Penta]: It's to protect school children.

[Robert Penta]: from obscene, sexually graphic, psychologically intrusive surveys conducted by the public schools without parental knowledge.

[Robert Penta]: The surveys also ask you to reveal their criminal activity, personal family matters, and other intimate issues.

[Robert Penta]: That's the legislation that House Bill number 382 describes itself to.

[Robert Penta]: I have no problem as a city councilor, and hopefully my council colleagues would be supportive of this.

[Robert Penta]: And I think it's fair to say

[Robert Penta]: There was an equal representation from both Democrats and Republicans on Beacon Hill who have signed on to support this bill.

[Robert Penta]: The piece of legislation that you're talking about dating back to, was it 1975, 1978 that you wrote it?

[Robert Penta]: And that piece of legislation is very explicit as it relates to surveys being disseminated by the public schools.

[Robert Penta]: for which parental notification needs to be given before the child either takes the survey or has the opt-out provision that they could take the survey.

[Robert Penta]: It's disturbing, and not to be repetitive, but when they ask questions, how old were you when you first had

[Robert Penta]: sex, annual, oral, vagina, for the first time.

[Robert Penta]: And then it says, you know, in the past three months, how many people have you had sex with?

[Robert Penta]: And it goes on to talk about whether you've taken cocaine, heroin.

[Robert Penta]: And it also talks about, do your parents text while they drive?

[Robert Penta]: And there's a whole host of issues.

[Robert Penta]: And I believe, if I understand it correctly in reading the bill and speaking to folks up in the Statehouse on the legislative committee, their concern is when a child goes to school, it's got to be more than making the child be physically safe.

[Robert Penta]: The child now has to be psychologically, emotionally not disturbed because of going to school and taking these type of surveys.

[Robert Penta]: And so to do that, they feel that this type of legislation would at least put the parent on an equal playing field.

[Robert Penta]: At least they would be advised of it.

[Robert Penta]: Now here in the city of Medford, I know you said, I think the survey was given in 2013.

[Robert Penta]: And some parents, again, once they find out after the fact, it's too late after the fact.

[Robert Penta]: I think another problem with these surveys, and some of these kids who are much younger, when they go to answer it, they may not know how to answer it.

[Robert Penta]: And they may just be writing all kinds of numbers that can escalate, yeah, 1, 5, 4, without really knowing.

[Robert Penta]: Maybe they don't even understand what the questions mean.

[Robert Penta]: How do you get somebody in the fourth, fifth, and the sixth grade to understand all of this?

[Robert Penta]: Yes, today, they may be more advanced because of what's on television and what's in the movies and stuff like that.

[Robert Penta]: But some of this stuff is really personal.

[Robert Penta]: And it's something that is a parental responsibility.

[Robert Penta]: It's their responsibility to make sure that their child understands what's on here if they are going to take it.

[Robert Penta]: So with that being said, it's not appropriate for the schools.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think it's appropriate for any school, public, private, or whatever, to make any decision on behalf of something that a parent has a responsibility and should have control over.

[Robert Penta]: A kid should not have to go to school, have that survey, and have the teacher say, we have to take this survey.

[Robert Penta]: And the parents have absolutely no idea on that particular day that that survey was given.

[Robert Penta]: And I think that's wrong.

[Robert Penta]: And I applaud you, and I applaud your organization and your efforts.

[Robert Penta]: And, you know, there's a state rep up from Lowell.

[Robert Penta]: His name is Randy Mom.

[Robert Penta]: And I believe he's a foreigner who immigrated here to this country, and unfortunate enough.

[Robert Penta]: And he said, this type of a survey is almost communistic, because he comes from a country, I believe it was Cambodia, and these are the type of questions that they would have to deal with.

[Robert Penta]: Right.

[Robert Penta]: And with that being said, Mr. President, I believe both chairpresidents from the House and Senate are not only in favor of it, but they appreciate the testimony that was given because it's being talked about.

[Robert Penta]: And maybe this can be sent back to the State Department of Education that you cannot.

[Robert Penta]: I mean, if you want to have these type of surveys to go out, communities and parents

[Robert Penta]: need to be informed ahead of time.

[Robert Penta]: The parent needs to see the survey, not be informed.

[Robert Penta]: They need to see the survey.

[Robert Penta]: Do you want your child to take the survey?

[Robert Penta]: And either they opt out or they opt in, one way or the other.

[Robert Penta]: But for what purpose it serves, I don't know, other than the fact that you're going to have some of these results turn around.

[Robert Penta]: And if I understand it correctly, in some cities and towns, these surveys were supposed to be anonymous, if I understood it correctly, but some people were identified by a number.

[Robert Penta]: And that doesn't speak well for a school system that allows that.

[Robert Penta]: So with that being said, Mr. President, I would move, and again, I would hope that the city council would support House Bill 382.

[Robert Penta]: I'll read it again.

[Robert Penta]: It's to protect schoolchildren from obscene, sexually graphic, psychologically intrusive surveys conducted by the public schools without

[Robert Penta]: parental knowledge.

[Robert Penta]: These surveys also seek to ask you to reveal their criminal activity, personal family matters, and other intimate issues.

[Robert Penta]: And it's House Bill 382.

[Robert Penta]: That's the bill.

[Robert Penta]: It's up in there was heard on, I believe, on May 6th.

[Robert Penta]: It was a full House.

[Robert Penta]: You had you had mothers there, you had single parents there, over and beyond mass resistance, and you had legislatures who spoke white, quite frankly, in favor of this because

[Robert Penta]: You know, this is something that just needs to be stopped before it gets out of hand.

[Robert Penta]: So that's the motion.

[Robert Penta]: Well, this is what the bill is, in essence.

[Robert Penta]: It's right there.

[Robert Penta]: I mean, I just read it to you what the gut of the bill is.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you, Councilor Camuso.

[Robert Penta]: Just as a point of clarification to Councilor Camuso's comments.

[Robert Penta]: Point of clarification.

[Robert Penta]: We have filed bills here from the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: that have made radical changes by the time it came out.

[Robert Penta]: All I'm talking about is the intent of what the bill wants to do.

[Robert Penta]: If the bill has to be amended, so be it.

[Robert Penta]: It may not even come out of committee, but it looks like it will come out of committee.

[Robert Penta]: The intent of this is to protect schoolchildren, but the law is very specific, as it's written right now, that parents, when surveys such as this are going to be disseminated, the parents need to be

[Robert Penta]: told ahead of time.

[Robert Penta]: Schools cannot just go out there and do it.

[Robert Penta]: And that's what the intent of this bill is.

[Robert Penta]: So all I'm asking you for is to support the intent of it.

[Robert Penta]: Then they can add it up, but to add it down after that, it's letting people know that, you know, if you want your child protected from this type of pornography in plain English, you know, now's the time to speak up.

[Robert Penta]: Councilor Camuso.

[Robert Penta]: Councilor Knight just made a remark that it's a hate organization.

[Robert Penta]: If it was such a hate organization, they wouldn't even be entertaining this on Beacon Hill, and they wouldn't be getting the support from both sides of the aisle.

[Robert Penta]: But to say that they're a hate organization, I don't see anything in front of me that says they're a hate organization.

[Robert Penta]: That's your opinion, for what you maybe read someplace.

[Robert Penta]: The gentleman at the podium, you indicated, sir, that the city of Medford in 2013 gave up that survey, correct?

[Robert Penta]: And that survey that was given out, parents weren't advised ahead of time.

[Robert Penta]: And they didn't see that survey before their child took it?

[Robert Penta]: On the motion, Councilor Penta.

[Robert Penta]: The lady that just spoke, I wholeheartedly disagree with her because number one, to say that the responsibility is on the parent.

[Robert Penta]: The responsibility can be not be on the parent if the parent doesn't know what's going on.

[Robert Penta]: The responsibility is within the public school system.

[Robert Penta]: If that's where these surveys are being disseminated through by the State Department of Education and they disseminate it to a public school,

[Robert Penta]: And then that has to go down to the student.

[Robert Penta]: The parents should be informed ahead of time that this type of a survey, and they should be able to read it ahead of time.

[Robert Penta]: So that way, their decision is informed.

[Robert Penta]: You can't take a fourth, a fifth, or a sixth grader and have them sign a survey or take a survey without a parent knowing it.

[Robert Penta]: That's wrong.

[Robert Penta]: That's the whole intent behind this piece of legislation, to inform the parent ahead of time.

[Robert Penta]: And that's what the law is, Chapter 71, Section 32A.

[Robert Penta]: That's what it says, and unfortunately,

[Robert Penta]: Cities and towns are not following the rules as they should.

[Robert Penta]: There's a motion before us.

[Robert Penta]: I can revert to it, and support the intent of House Bill 382, which is to protect children from obscene, sexually graphic, and psychologically intrusive service.

[Robert Penta]: I have it here for you, Eddie.

[Robert Penta]: Um, let me see.

[Robert Penta]: It's 283.

[Robert Penta]: It's 283.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, last Thursday at 2 o'clock in the afternoon in this council chamber, an ascertainment hearing took place and it's related to the Comcast contract.

[Robert Penta]: that I believed everybody in the room that day, except the gentleman, Mr. Epstein, who was sitting up conducting the hearing, knew that the hearing or the date of April 18th, which was the ending date of the city's contract with Comcast, had been extended to July.

[Robert Penta]: Now, unbeknownst to all of us until we were speaking at the podium on that day, oh, let me preface this by saying there wasn't one person.

[Robert Penta]: There wasn't one person here from the city administration to speak on the contract.

[Robert Penta]: to defend it, to defend the taxpayers, the ratepayers within this community, to the concerns that they might have as it relates to all of these particular issues.

[Robert Penta]: And as a result of that, there was seven or eight citizens.

[Robert Penta]: Some spoke.

[Robert Penta]: Some didn't speak.

[Robert Penta]: I think six of them did speak.

[Robert Penta]: And a lot of the major concerns were as follows.

[Robert Penta]: But I just want to, you know, there was a certified mail sent by the mayor of this community on April 16th, two days before, two days before,

[Robert Penta]: the deadline, which was April 18.

[Robert Penta]: And according to the federal law, which supersedes state law, this continuance takes place until July 3 of this year coming up.

[Robert Penta]: So residents who have any concerns as it relates to Comcast, the renewal of the cable contract, have up until May 21 to submit their formal complaints to the mayor of this community.

[Robert Penta]: And they will be officially forwarded to the State Cable Commission in Boston and to Mr. Peter Epstein

[Robert Penta]: who is the paid legal consultant for the city.

[Robert Penta]: But some of the comments that were made, number one, the 10-year contract, way, way, way too long.

[Robert Penta]: Another part of the comments were the issuing authority taking it out of the mayor's hands and putting it into the legislative body, like it is in some other cities and towns.

[Robert Penta]: There's no senior citizen discount.

[Robert Penta]: The increase in cost just keeps going up each and every year as it relates to Comcast.

[Robert Penta]: And with the new addition,

[Robert Penta]: of the technology that's out there between Amazon and Apple and a whole host of other individuals in this business, a 10-year contract would serve no purpose for the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: A three to a five-year contract seems to be something that would be palatable and it would be something that could possibly be written that could find itself with renewable terminology.

[Robert Penta]: Also, there was no explanation because it never took place of any survey that ever took place here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: with Comcast customers over the past 10 years, whether they were satisfied, dissatisfied, or what they would like to see.

[Robert Penta]: Also, there was no mention of the fact that the mass cable division indicates that ascertainment hearings need to take place within 12 months prior to the expiration date, but no later than six months prior to.

[Robert Penta]: We never had that within 12 months, and we never had that within six months.

[Robert Penta]: That's not from me.

[Robert Penta]: That's from the cable division form

[Robert Penta]: 100 and that's part of their proceeding operating procedures Also, we have the discussion on the particular perks are in kind benefits that this mayor has received as a result of having this contract with Comcast what was indicated at that meeting there were 52 cities and towns throughout the country or 52 mares for which we were one of them that wrote a letter in support of having a merger between Time Warner and Comcast

[Robert Penta]: The mayor was quoted in picture form in the magazines that proffer the cable industry as being a shill for Comcast, because number one, he received on an annual basis $2,500 for his annual golf tournament, and he got $10,000 a year for his celebrations committee.

[Robert Penta]: That in and of itself

[Robert Penta]: was a concern because no one else, no rate payer has that opportunity to get that for whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: Also, there needed to be a complete review of the records of the public access corporation, minutes of the meeting, financial records, bank accounts, and all of that.

[Robert Penta]: That has never taken place.

[Robert Penta]: Comcast themselves have never taken the opportunity to review it.

[Robert Penta]: They've never taken an inventory of the PEG facilities, and they haven't looked at the lifespan of the equipment that they have at the same time.

[Robert Penta]: And there was no strategic plan to be presented for the PEG programming as a result of that.

[Robert Penta]: And the access corporation, in and of itself, needs to be in good standing by having its annual reports and its financial filings and its proper forms in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, for which they don't have.

[Robert Penta]: These are all things that Comcast has not done as it relates to this.

[Robert Penta]: Comcast has not had any public hearings themselves to encourage commentary from people, from the citizens.

[Robert Penta]: It was brought up at that meeting that the city council voted on two separate occasions.

[Robert Penta]: One, to have the public hearing and two, to have the public hearing at a reasonable time, which would have been two o'clock in the afternoon.

[Robert Penta]: What the mayor decided to do was to have, he canceled out the first meeting on a Thursday and forwarded to the next Thursday meeting, which was last week, and still had it at two o'clock in the afternoon because there was hardly anybody here.

[Robert Penta]: People were working.

[Robert Penta]: And some people who were here, including myself, felt that that was a slight.

[Robert Penta]: And it was a slight.

[Robert Penta]: It was slight to the rate payers within this community.

[Robert Penta]: There was nothing by way of a document that would indicate that a survey was taken by Comcast for the purposes of ascertaining community needs.

[Robert Penta]: And the results of the survey were not included or submitted to the issuing authority in this particular case was the mayor.

[Robert Penta]: Usually the way it will go, the town usually sends out an RFP, or in this particular case, if we're talking about a renewal to the contract, then that renewal to the contract generally takes about 30 to 90 days for the issuing authority to review it.

[Robert Penta]: And then four months after the issuing authority reviews it, the proposal from the cable contractor or the operator at that point in time can once again be received.

[Robert Penta]: The city does not have to accept it.

[Robert Penta]: The city can send it back.

[Robert Penta]: The city can reject it.

[Robert Penta]: or they can consider the contract in a shorter term of period and time.

[Robert Penta]: The new legislative landscape on this particular negotiation on long-term contracts has now been considered to be anywhere from three to five to seven years.

[Robert Penta]: I think that would be something that could be palatable if the terminology was written in there that, inclusive of that language, there would be a review done by Comcast for the things that we talked about that they haven't been doing.

[Robert Penta]: The commercial districts were brought up.

[Robert Penta]: Councilor Marks' indication relative the lack of connectivity to certain parts of the square.

[Robert Penta]: That was brought up, that was a point brought up I believe by two other individuals as well as myself.

[Robert Penta]: That in and of itself really showed that Comcast has not gone out of its way for the purposes of connectivity.

[Robert Penta]: Again, it's another failing on their part to make sure that the city was completely and totally hooked up for Comcast.

[Robert Penta]: They indicated also too,

[Robert Penta]: that the reducing of INET expenses or negotiating for cable modem installations, which is more and the least costly, could be challenged by the 6 megahertz channels, which are high-definition channels to the cable operator.

[Robert Penta]: There was also the request that we could avoid agreeing with the cable operator's right to reclaim unused channel time.

[Robert Penta]: That's one thing I believe that Comcast has done through the years.

[Robert Penta]: If a cable channel is not being used,

[Robert Penta]: They've reclaimed it, and they've put it into a higher tier.

[Robert Penta]: Those are some of the issues in an overview that took place in that particular meeting.

[Robert Penta]: Once again, if anybody oh, yeah, strike that.

[Robert Penta]: And also, lastly, performance review hearings, a request to hold hearings on an annual or as-needed basis, contractually obligate the cable operator's attendance.

[Robert Penta]: That has never been done by Comcast.

[Robert Penta]: So these were the things, these were the nuts and bolts, these were the ingredients that were talked about and presented.

[Robert Penta]: 85 cities and towns have now signed on to this.

[Robert Penta]: Today I attended a mass municipal board meeting and one of their highlights is this MS for permitting part of this permitting process that the EPA is forthcoming.

[Robert Penta]: As a matter of fact, today it was recognized for the first time that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts is complementing cities and towns who are taking a stand on this particular position and challenging the EPA, the federal EPA, on this particular mandate, which is not only going to be costly, it's going to be almost prohibitive for the city and town to do this within the next five years.

[Robert Penta]: It's an excess of 13, I believe, over $20 billion

[Robert Penta]: entity as it's going to relate upon the entire Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

[Robert Penta]: This is nothing more than having our city engineer write a letter in support of our community, sister communities.

[Robert Penta]: She doesn't believe what I'm saying.

[Robert Penta]: We're a member of MMA.

[Robert Penta]: She can call them up and ask them, you know, what it's all about.

[Robert Penta]: She can check in with their environmental committee.

[Robert Penta]: You know, all we're doing is requesting the APA that since the proposed MS4 stormwater

[Robert Penta]: sewer system permit would require communities to institute more advanced stormwater testing, monitoring, and management programs, but is completely silent on funding or mitigation of the additional costs to communities.

[Robert Penta]: And since there is no flexibility in the compliance portion of the requirements, and since communities are grappling with these huge financial challenges, with preliminary projections to be in excess of $800,000 per year per community, we ask the EPA to defer action on their submission

[Robert Penta]: of a notice of intent until municipalities have had the opportunity to engage the regulatory agencies in an open dialogue regarding these onerous and unaffordable permit requirements.

[Robert Penta]: And then it goes on and explains and it gives a whole list of these things.

[Robert Penta]: And I just don't understand why we have not received.

[Robert Penta]: I think it was Councilor Knight.

[Robert Penta]: I think in the beginning you sort of like okayed with that and you said, can we just send it upstairs and let's see if we can get an answer back.

[Robert Penta]: Well, we haven't gotten an answer back from her.

[Robert Penta]: And this is too important of an issue.

[Robert Penta]: They did a survey of Massachusetts cities and towns.

[Robert Penta]: This was their second highest priority through Mass.

[Robert Penta]: Municipal Association, for which we are a paid dues member within that community.

[Robert Penta]: This is huge.

[Robert Penta]: This is huge as it relates to an infrastructure problem here in the city of Medford, as it relates to our water and sewer, especially our stormwater and sewer provisions.

[Robert Penta]: This is a very aggressive attitude.

[Robert Penta]: being taken by the EPA.

[Robert Penta]: What the Commonwealth of Massachusetts is doing, and the Baker administration, and the Commonwealth's EPA program, they're asking for a long-term, at least a minimum, of a 20-year program that forecasts out cities and towns to go at this at a reasonable pace and at a reasonable cost.

[Robert Penta]: The city of Medford cannot afford $800,000 a year to correct all its stormwater provisions.

[Robert Penta]: That's minimum.

[Robert Penta]: Could even be more on that.

[Robert Penta]: We have things going on upstairs.

[Robert Penta]: in our water and sewer department that's going to be costing us probably into the millions with a new program that they're going to be coming up on a leak detection program.

[Robert Penta]: And then when we look at that, how's the priority run against that against this?

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, I'm asking that we as a city or our Medford City Council go forward with a letter of support, forward this to the Commonwealth of Massachusetts EBA and letting them know that we support their proposal

[Robert Penta]: for forecasting this over a longer period of time, having an educational program for which there is none being offered by the federal EPA, and at the same time, give cities and towns an opportunity to forecast their financial program to engage in this program.

[Robert Penta]: Also, there are five coalitions of eastern Massachusetts towns, which make up over 85 communities that surround us that are looking into combining their services, their expertise,

[Robert Penta]: and whatever it takes to reduce the individual city and town burden to get through this process.

[Robert Penta]: So again, going through all our resolutions that haven't been answered, there's a whole host of them.

[Robert Penta]: If this is the mayor's intent to just leave and just ignore this council or have a department head ignore this council on this most important issue, shame on all of them.

[Robert Penta]: This is too important an issue.

[Robert Penta]: It affects every single taxpayer, water and soil projection, water and soil rate payer,

[Robert Penta]: in this particular community.

[Robert Penta]: So I ask approval, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: And if you want, I'll read the entire resolution.

[Robert Penta]: No thanks.

[Robert Penta]: In the resolution.

[Robert Penta]: Yes, that's the exact text.

[Robert Penta]: This Craddock Bridge is an integral part as to what's happening in Medford Square.

[Robert Penta]: And the fact of the matter is that we've been talking about this thing, I think, dating back to 2007, if I think.

[Robert Penta]: I think the very first resolution on the Craddock Bridge is owned by Councilor Lungo-Koehn going back to 2004 regarding the safety of the bridge on a question that was brought up.

[Robert Penta]: And she then forwarded that to the council as part of a resolution.

[Robert Penta]: And subsequent to that, it's been resolution after resolution and after resolution.

[Robert Penta]: And if this bridge was in such terrible disrepair, and if it was sinking and afraid to come apart and crumbling, we wouldn't even be talking about this right now, because it would be done.

[Robert Penta]: We're not asking for a $13 million bridge that the state wants to put together.

[Robert Penta]: It's sitting on solid granite that's been there in excess of 100 years.

[Robert Penta]: We're just looking for a bridge that can handle traversing traffic.

[Robert Penta]: That's all.

[Robert Penta]: We're not looking for a state of the art,

[Robert Penta]: mausoleum type of a bridge that we can say, oh, wow.

[Robert Penta]: And that's how the state gets itself in trouble, especially with spending its money without looking at the simple characteristic of putting a bridge, putting a roadway back together to let the cars go through.

[Robert Penta]: And if the locks have a problem that need to be resolved, then address it as a separate issue or a joint issue at the same time.

[Robert Penta]: But to have this thing go out that started off as a $2.5 million, then it went up to $14 million, now it's back to $11 million, then it goes up to $12 million,

[Robert Penta]: Even they don't even know what's going on in the state, because we don't even know what the state is going to cost in real time when they begin to do it.

[Robert Penta]: And then when they're talking about it's going to be done within 1,300 calendar days from the receipt of the notice to proceed, well, that's an awful lot of time, 1,300 calendar days.

[Robert Penta]: And even if you split that in half, because they work double time or whatever it might be, that's over 650 days.

[Robert Penta]: I mean, there's got to be an explanation that's better.

[Robert Penta]: They could do fast 14.

[Robert Penta]: in 12 weekends during the course of a summer, then they could make a bridge that could be working for the Craddock Bridge, build it ahead of time, and come in maybe in a week's period of time or in a couple weeks to do it.

[Robert Penta]: You know, I'm just disappointed in our city engineer not even responding back to us on this.

[Robert Penta]: I'm also disappointed the Office of Community Development, knowing now that they were excluded from it, has not stuck their two cents in there to find out why were they excluded.

[Robert Penta]: And deeply disappointed because the mayor, he doesn't respond to anything with us.

[Robert Penta]: So that's a given.

[Robert Penta]: This whole issue has been predicated on the council's involvement on this particular matter.

[Robert Penta]: We're looking for mitigation.

[Robert Penta]: We have absolutely no concern from anybody as it relates to this issue of mitigation.

[Robert Penta]: If the mayor was the mayor, he'd be out there fighting tooth and nail that before this bid goes out, there'd be some form of mitigation for any sense of disruption that may takes place here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know where we're going, Mr. President, but all I can tell you is this, and I'm not looking into a crystal ball, but maybe I am.

[Robert Penta]: If the mayor leaves before this term is over and you assume the position of mayor of this city, because that's what the charter says, then I would expect you to have a decision before this council immediately as to time, date, place, and mitigation of this bridge, because you've been just as much a part of this as anyone else has been.

[Robert Penta]: You've been aware of this just as much as anyone else has been.

[Robert Penta]: And if you do the same thing that the guy in the corner office has done by not communicating, then the shame is going to be on you.

[Robert Penta]: And I would hope that that does not rest on your shoulders, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: Can I ask you a question?

[Robert Penta]: Yes, the question is, when did you find out about this?

[Robert Penta]: Yesterday, and you're bringing it to the council tonight, and you expect me by 10 o'clock tomorrow morning, for which I already have another engagement, to be there.

[Robert Penta]: He had been speaking to the clerk.
