[Robert Penta]: But the sad part to all of this whole story

[Robert Penta]: It's going to take place tomorrow at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, because we have what they call an ascertainment hearing at 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

[Robert Penta]: Excuse me, Thursday afternoon.

[Robert Penta]: Excuse me, Thursday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

[Robert Penta]: And the sad part about having this ascertainment hearing on Thursday at 2 o'clock is the contract with Comcast has already come to an end.

[Robert Penta]: So technically, we're actually working with them as a tenant at will.

[Robert Penta]: This ascertainment hearing should have taken place at minimum six months to a year prior to the contract closing.

[Robert Penta]: So what's going to be accomplished at this hearing is not going to make any sense at all.

[Robert Penta]: But the only sense that it will make is for people to come and tell them why you don't like what you're getting, whether the folks at Comcast are rude or they're not rude, whether the fees are too high, whether the channels should be a la carte or individual, or whether the programming should have a whole different type of an appetite, and to show what comparisons might be between Verizon and Comcast.

[Robert Penta]: As a matter of fact, Comcast has been voted

[Robert Penta]: the worst corporation in the country for customer services on the national agenda.

[Robert Penta]: And our mayor was one of 52 who wrote letters to the Federal Trade Commission for the purposes of allowing Comcast to be bought into this merger with Time Warner, thankfully that they did not allow because they felt that the corporate conglomerate would just destroy this whole idea.

[Robert Penta]: not only of public access, but for televising, what do you call it, bandwidth and broadband.

[Robert Penta]: So these are all technical things that are beyond my imagination for understanding, but all I know is having an understanding.

[Robert Penta]: But when they turn around and put a picture of our present mayor on a story with other mayors saying that he was a shill for Comcast, and he was a shill, and they went down to explain

[Robert Penta]: that the reason is because on an annual basis, got $10,000 a year for a celebration committee, got $2,500 each and every year for his golf tournament.

[Robert Penta]: And when you start thinking about that and you hear people talk about it, they're saying, wait a minute, we're not paying.

[Robert Penta]: I'm not paying my cable bill so he can have a golf tournament every year.

[Robert Penta]: I'm not paying my cable bill so he can have a celebration committee.

[Robert Penta]: And that's a cost that's built right in to everyone's cable fee.

[Robert Penta]: Comcast isn't giving this for nothing.

[Robert Penta]: They know what the cost is to give out those perks to those 52 mayors who signed on and were termed shills for Comcast.

[Robert Penta]: That's a hell of a way to go out of office, being known that you were shill, leaving the city all upside down with these crazy meters in the square, and God knows what else is going to happen.

[Robert Penta]: The fact of the matter is,

[Robert Penta]: We have a terrible contract here with Comcast, and nothing should be signed until a new mayor comes on board.

[Robert Penta]: So if we have to stay on as nothing more than a tenant, so be it.

[Robert Penta]: I'm going to ask that this council make a request that the mayor does not sign any new 10-year contract with Comcast and until a new administration comes on board.

[Robert Penta]: Isn't it interesting?

[Robert Penta]: They took the same thing when they were trying to hire a new public works director.

[Robert Penta]: They went through the whole process, and then they decided to stop.

[Robert Penta]: Let the new mayor come in.

[Robert Penta]: Let the new mayor hire that person.

[Robert Penta]: We have a stupid kiosk program that's a 10-year contract.

[Robert Penta]: And we have a contract right now that's not in operation,

[Robert Penta]: which is the tail end of a Comcast contract, which is all over, it's expired.

[Robert Penta]: not to engage and not to sign any contract with Comcast.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, today, as you know, I'm assuming all of you know that the mayor signed this contract tonight around 517 or thereabouts.

[Robert Penta]: He signed the contract.

[Robert Penta]: And he makes a notation that the council was in support of this.

[Robert Penta]: And we did on September 10th.

[Robert Penta]: But when the pushback came back, the mayor decided not to go forward at that time.

[Robert Penta]: And speaking to Mr. Skelton,

[Robert Penta]: are referring to Mr. Skelton's comments from Republic.

[Robert Penta]: From the 10th to the 25th of September, there was absolutely no communication between the mayor and Republic.

[Robert Penta]: So something had to take place from the 24th to today, the 7th.

[Robert Penta]: And taking that into consideration, it's quite obvious that the chamber's concerns, oh, I don't know who wrote the letter because we don't have a copy of the letter.

[Robert Penta]: He says he got a letter from the chamber.

[Robert Penta]: But when you have four separate squares, including Medford Square, which makes five, and their issues are all unique,

[Robert Penta]: and they needed to be heard, and they weren't heard, and the mayor decides to have one size fits all, I don't think that's what you call a happy resolution, especially to the business people and to the taxpayers of this community.

[Robert Penta]: You know, the fact of the matter is this.

[Robert Penta]: We're getting rid of people who don't live in the community, who were parking at spots all day long, and they haven't been tagged.

[Robert Penta]: And this has been going on for the entire years of the administration of this city, this mayor.

[Robert Penta]: And now what we're going to be doing is tagging, if not towing, and telling our own taxpayers in this community, you people are going to have to start paying.

[Robert Penta]: Now, right up front, no free parking unless you are lucky enough to get one of those two spots in any one of the four or five sections of this community.

[Robert Penta]: Where it's going, I don't know, Mr. President, but all I can tell you is this.

[Robert Penta]: If I had to put my money on something, I would put it on public safety, the police department, the personnel that's needed to keep this community safe,

[Robert Penta]: And more importantly, the subject matters that I brought up under the police department.

[Robert Penta]: Those to me are pressing needs.

[Robert Penta]: They have no comparison, no comparison at all to a parking paid to park program or enforcement.

[Robert Penta]: If the mayor was so concerned about that paid to park program and enforcement, he should have done it years ago, but he didn't.

[Robert Penta]: And when they knew that people from Winchester and other communities were coming here and parking all day and not getting tagged and ticketed, he should have done something, but he didn't.

[Robert Penta]: So,

[Robert Penta]: put $300,000 this first year out of the box, compare everything to what the police department needs to keep our community safe and protected.

[Robert Penta]: It's pale in comparison.

[Robert Penta]: And with that being said, Mr. President, I just wanted to say that, um, I just think, you know, this council is either going to be committed to public safety and a new PlayStation and the police department, or this is nothing more than hot air every Tuesday night when we come here to talk about public safety.

[Robert Penta]: We have more than enough examples.

[Robert Penta]: And I think we have more than enough good police officers.

[Robert Penta]: The shooting is just a drop in the bucket compared to all the drug problems that are existing throughout this community.

[Robert Penta]: And that's a concern.

[Robert Penta]: And if they had more personnel, and if they could go to court, and if they had more of the mechanisms and the technology that is needed, it would be great.

[Robert Penta]: You know, when you talk to someone, you say, hey, you're building a brand new public works department, $14 million.

[Robert Penta]: $14 million.

[Robert Penta]: Still don't even have enough men to man it.

[Robert Penta]: But you have a police department that's ready to fall apart.

[Robert Penta]: You have an evidence room that's completely out of control and a whole host of other issues.

[Robert Penta]: So, I would say, Mr. President and my fellow colleagues, that I think it's time that we take the stand and we tell the mayor we want a new police station.

[Robert Penta]: I don't care how you fund it.

[Robert Penta]: You found the money for a public works department, then find the money for a police station.

[Robert Penta]: Because you're not going to make one seem to be more important than another.

[Robert Penta]: And at the same time, you're not going to put the lives of this community and the folks in this community at risk.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, um, I guess I missed this when I was reading it.

[Robert Penta]: Every other person or every other type of an account will be charged 0.138.

[Robert Penta]: Now, does that mean that that's going to be a commercial rate?

[Robert Penta]: And 165, Section 2B is very explicit

[Robert Penta]: where it talks about, shall institute water charges and fees that incorporate a base rate for all, provided, which means other than or maybe, that said base rate shall be increased at an increased block rate to fairly reflect the resource demand and consumption of high volume uses of water.

[Robert Penta]: Now think about high volume uses of water.

[Robert Penta]: If you live in a three-family house, for the example that they use, you are a single person on the first floor.

[Robert Penta]: There is two, three people on the third floor, five or six people on the third floor.

[Robert Penta]: And they use the example you used, 2,100 units of water.

[Robert Penta]: Well, they're going to take the 2,100 units of water, divide it by three, and everybody's going to be tagged with 700 units of water to be charged.

[Robert Penta]: That doesn't make any sense at all, number one, because number one,

[Robert Penta]: Not everybody has a meter in their apartment.

[Robert Penta]: And if it's a single meter that's going to cover the whole house, some houses are like that.

[Robert Penta]: So 800 getting to the baseline, how did you get to it?

[Robert Penta]: Where did you come up with that number?

[Robert Penta]: Because if you look at a lot of the residential homes, they're going to be between 800 and that 1,600 mark.

[Robert Penta]: So by going over by one cubic feet, you're going to be putting that residential homeowner, who might have two or three kids or taking care of a senior citizen, paying a higher rate.

[Robert Penta]: And that's where I think the discussion needs to take place.

[Robert Penta]: I'm not denying the fact that the more you use, the more you should pay.

[Robert Penta]: But this is a big gap from $800 to $800 to $1,600.

[Robert Penta]: And if you are just a little bit over that, you're going to be saddled with that additional thing.

[Robert Penta]: And again, as I said, if somebody has multiple people living in their family home, they're going to be penalized for using the water.

[Robert Penta]: If they use a dramatic amount, that's one thing.

[Robert Penta]: Yeah, clarification.

[Robert Penta]: Okay.

[Robert Penta]: I hear what Councilor Knight is alluding to.

[Robert Penta]: The point is valid.

[Robert Penta]: It went from zero to 1,000.

[Robert Penta]: Why did it come down to 800?

[Robert Penta]: Now, if you speak to some of the members, they're going to turn around and tell you, this is part of the conservation mode of saving water and within families and stuff like that.

[Robert Penta]: Which I wholeheartedly support.

[Robert Penta]: Right.

[Robert Penta]: But I don't think anybody's going to deny the fact that, you know, you don't want to penalize people because they have people living in their homes.

[Robert Penta]: who might be seniors or elderly or babies or two or three children or for whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: And I would be not in favor of having a subcommittee.

[Robert Penta]: I would be in favor of just having, calling for the public hearing and have them come in and explain it.

[Robert Penta]: They've already mean what they did.

[Robert Penta]: And one point further, and I think as a Councilor, Councilor Marks, I think we had this conversation.

[Robert Penta]: Getting to the point of the households, as Councilor Knight has just alluded to, how did you make this determination?

[Robert Penta]: Where are the numbers of those homes that are between 0 to 800, and from 800 to 1,600, and over that?

[Robert Penta]: They have to have statistics to do that, because if they just decided to go to 800 because it sounded good, because it was a good conservation move, well, that's not good.

[Robert Penta]: If there's people between 800 and 850, whatever it might be, there's nothing wrong with going to 1,000.

[Robert Penta]: I mean, that's a compromise.

[Robert Penta]: I got no problem with that.

[Robert Penta]: But I want to see these numbers.

[Robert Penta]: I want to see these numbers.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you for your point.

[Robert Penta]: I just remind councilor Dello Russo, one thing we had asked at one point in time,

[Robert Penta]: to have our city engineer appear before the council.

[Robert Penta]: And she didn't come because the mayor told her not to come.

[Robert Penta]: OK.

[Robert Penta]: So we can ask the Water and Soil Commissioners to come.

[Robert Penta]: But if they choose not to come because they're told not to come, where does that put the council?

[Robert Penta]: Point of clarification, Councilor Penta.

[Robert Penta]: The law says explicitly if the estimated income is more than the total appropriations, the excess shall be appropriated to a separate reserve fund and used for capital expenditures of the enterprise subject to the appropriation or to reduce user charges if authorized by the appropriate entity.

[Robert Penta]: responsible for operations of the enterprise.

[Robert Penta]: He can the law.

[Robert Penta]: Absolutely.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, also the letter indicates further down that they're going to keep this baseline rate for the first year.

[Robert Penta]: So the intention is that they're going to be going up.

[Robert Penta]: So with that being said,

[Robert Penta]: I'm going to make the request that the Board of Water and Soil Commissioners appear before the Medford City Council to discuss this letter that went out that's unsigned, undated, as it represents, and that a new bill be forthcoming.

[Robert Penta]: They revised the bill that includes the rate for the water and the rate for the sewage.

[Robert Penta]: and along with the total amount.

[Robert Penta]: They don't have the old use by consumption and water and sewer charges.

[Robert Penta]: There was absolutely nothing.

[Robert Penta]: You notice that the mayor did not.

[Robert Penta]: sitting in the surplus account.
